Some commenters have pointed out that we say "after our lineage split with chimpanzees," "members of our lineage after the split with chimpanzees," and "after our split from chimpanzees" at various points in this episode. Just to clear things up, humans and our extinct relatives share a common ancestor with chimpanzees and their extinct relatives. After our lineage split from this common ancestor, we call our group "hominins." Living chimpanzees also have their own separate evolutionary history since that shared common ancestor.

Pretty sure that the real reason most  humans are right handed has something to do with asymmetry of the diaphragm. The right diaphragm is a larger stronger muscle than the left side. This can set up a series of posture biases all throughout the body. This is called the Left AIC pattern.

Theory of evolution lol
It's more complicated than that.  If the palm is facing downward or away from the person, a right handed person will have more dexterity using the right hand, but if a right handed person is working with the palm facing upward, or toward them, they will have more dexterity using the left hand.  Example, for a guitar player, the hand pressing strings against frets requires more dexterity, for a right handed player, that's going to be the left hand, for a left handed player that's going to be the right hand.  Other instruments such a flute and woodwinds, the right handed person will prefer the right hand facing down or away from them, and the left hand facing up or toward them.  Drummers using traditional grip, same thing.  I'm sure examples other than playing a musical instrument could be made.

My guess as to why we prefer one hand over the other is that it would take too much brain power/development to have both hands on max skill level. You unlock most benefits from one very coordinated hand so developing 2 hands to that level would waste energy.   So with this thesis most animals have 2 left hands. They never developed them to be as proficient as human hands therefore don‚Äôt need to decide which one to prioritize.

Our heart is positioned in the left section of our chest. If our ancestors chose to guard their torso with their left arm they would have higher survival rate over those who chose to guard their torso with the right arm. The right arm would then become the dominant hand for reaching out from the body while the left was more inclined to stay close to the body. It would be an evolutionary advantage simply because our heart is more to the left side in our body. This would make the majority right-handed and the minority left-handed because that is how things balance out with things like a slightly off-center vital organ within a bipedal species.
I‚Äôm not sure he‚Äôs correct about us splitting from chimpanzees. I believe we‚Äôre distant cousins of chimpanzees not descendants.

My great grandfather was a leftie but he was beaten in school until he learned to use his right hand. What if ten percent of Neanderthal were left Handed? You have no way of knowing, there aren‚Äôt that many specimens. People are mostly right handed now, they probably always have been.
My theory is that handedness is connected to spatial cognition.  Generally speaking, the right side of our brains (which controls the left side of our bodies) dominates abstract thought while the left side of our brains (which controls the right side of our bodies) dominates concrete thought.  A primitive hunter tries to pick off a bird by throwing a rock; the concept originates in the right hemisphere, but the execution is carried out by the left hemisphere.  In an age when such proficiency was key to both survival and reproduction (particularly for males), it's easy to understand why our ancestors were almost exclusively right-handed.  Two other factors which come into play are genetic variation and the advent of civilization.  Owing to our dimorphic natures, genetic variation is far more common among males than females - plotted out, nearly all women exist within the first deviation; the second deviation is overwhelmingly male, while the third deviation is almost exclusively male.  We see this in most every aspect of society, where men dominate both the upper and lower extremes while women 'safely' cluster in the middle.  Given women's roles in procreation, it is similarly easy to understand why this is so.  But that is arguably why most lefties are men.  Since the advent of civilization, such proficiency isn't as essential to survival as it was previously.  Abstract cognition is often as successful as concrete cognition; though we're still heavily skewed towards "doers", society has evolved a niche for "thinkers" as well.  As such, lefties aren't as vulnerable (and, by extension, weeded from the gene pool) as in ancient times; since left-handed men are no longer excluded from procreation, that trait is increasingly passed along to female offspring as well.
I‚Äôm right handed, but I shoot a gun left handed, and I also skateboard with my right foot forward.

One of the trade off for lefties is playing musical instruments, notably guitar and drums. For drums I need to completely rearrange every drum set I'm going to play, because I can't kick with right foot (lower power and messy coordination) so I kick with left foot and move the snare to the right.

The assertion that left handedness confers an advantage only while it is rare, so it remains rare must be an evolutionary fallacy. Think about the left handed individuals who have an advantage who then reproduce more. Equilibrium will be restored between righties and lefties. The lefties will not suddenly suffer a disadvantage against righties to make them die out and return to the optimum level!

I'm wondering if any right-hand vs. left-hand studies take into consideration every single activity that a lefty does and the hand they use for those. I'm a lefty, and I do use my left hand to write, hold the fork while I eat, and brush my teeth. If I need to clean the house, I'll wipe furniture with it too. However, to wipe myself in the bathroom, I use my right hand. Same to bounce the ball when I play basketball or hold the upper part of a broom when I sweep the floor. If I'm walking my dog, I hold the leash with either hand and use my phone with either hand that is available. I'll change a light bulb with my right hand, hold cups with either, but if it's a mug or anything with a handle, I'll use my left hand. To lock or unlock the door, I'll use my right hand. Therefore, I wouldn't affirm that left-handed people manipulate every tool with their left hand. I don't know about right-handed ones.

To state the obvious, most internal organs (Liver, heart, gut) are not symetrical, being able to protect one side better may have an advantage, or it may be better blood supply or nerve supply to one side makes gives a bias to that side. As a guess the degree of danger to asymetric organs when hunting or being hunted, may select for "handedness", and is less of an issue for say chimps.

As a left-handed person, I typically learn either by copying in mirror image, or by copying exactly and then transposing later.  But to teach, I find that I must physically reverse everything for most people.    I spent about 12 years learning how to use hand-to-hand weapons of the middle ages.  In tournament bouts--especially with sword and shield--many opponents did not even clue in to my left-handedness until they had already lost the bout.  Even when they did notice or entered the bout knowing this about me, the lines were all wrong for them and generally difficult.  On the flip side, 99.9999% of my match ups were essentially identical in this regard.  Where left-handedness is a detriment is in the trades.  Anything that rotates--like a drill--wants to rip itself out of your hand when it encounters too much resistance (the screw bottoms out, the bit seizes, etc.).  Not fun when you're at the top of a ladder using a hammer drill overhead.

Whenever the subject of handedness comes up, I bring up card tricks.  One of the "secrets" is that you train all of the flashy stuff in you non-dominant hand, so the very technical hidden stuff can be done deftly with your dominant hand.  As a result, after a while you're non-dominant hand can just *do things* your dominant hand can't do.  And trying to do those things feels like writing with your off hand.  The feeling this gives me is that there's a lot of *learned* behavior in handedness.  Which makes me think that cultures that write from right to left would have more left handed individuals, as a matter of learned convenience.  Same as baseball players or boxers over-representing left-handedness.  Nope.  It's about 10% everywhere.  Which heavily indicates a genetic component over a cultural one.  Basically, in the nature vs nurture debate, I think handedness might be the single most compelling example of "It's a bit of both, mixed with statistics in both cases."

Its much more more simple that all this... Most animals dont need fine motor skills to survive (at least not anywhere close to the level humans do). Because almost all fine motor skills take a long time to train, AND the brain controls the body with different sides of the brain (meaning you would need to learn each skill twice to be truly ambidextrous) it is simply better for humans to be handed. Now why right handed? Its one of 2 reasons. 1) that is just how people passed down knowledge, or 2) we diverged to have the left side of the brain handle "more" fine motar skills, and the right side handle more gross motor skills (im sure a neuro scientist can help me with that). and it could be a combo of both...

Save 10 min of your life :  Right handed majority seems due to a specific brain area linked with the use of tools. This area is located on the left side of the brain (which control the right side of the body). So, as our ancestors started to use tools, they became more right handed.  (just a theory)

It's simple. The right side of the brain controls the left side of the body the right side of the brain is the imagination side of the brain... it deals in things that are not real.  The left side of the brain controls the right side of the body the left side of the brain is the fact based side of the brain that deals with reality... it deals with things that are real.  Therefore, since survival depends on understanding reality the left side of the brain is focused on things and facts and is therefore, use of the left side of the brain results in success and survival and the favor of the right side of the brain results in failure.  There are studies performed on individuals who have had half of their brains removed either the left or right side and when their hands are isolated the left side of the brain causes the hand to reach for things that exist and the right side of the brain causes the hand to search for things that are imaginary.   ...look it up.

It's always been because of our brains. As our brains developed thru generations of time, our brains cognitive and creative side allowed for more fine dexterity work with fingers and hands. It was probably a slow process, that over time, those who used that advantage were rewarded with better quality fine workmanship, of say tools or weapons, and abilities of marksmanship in throwing a spear, etc. Since logic controls our left side of our brain, and we use logic throughout the day, it was more natural for our brains to pick up more and more fine motor skills in our right hand, and probably foot as well.
I remember reading somewhere that some right handed people can easily switch to left with some training, but not Vice versa.  They looked at people who can drive in the US system and the English system and right handed people had significant advantage of cross dexterity. Basically Right handed people have silent left handed mess which can be programmed to emerge. However it said, Left handedness seem to be more neurological related and people with dominant left hand have more memory, artistic abilities etc.. Fascinating stuff

Very simple explanation for this and supported by MRI scans and studies done to patients who had epilepsy leading to strokes in the 50's and 60's. The left side of your brain controls the logic center and the right side the creative center of reasoning. Basically, the left side of your brain who is the best at drawing controls your right hand directly and thus everyone is right handed unless you train yourself to not use your right brain for left sided activity. MRI scans show when people draw with the left hand and right hand the left side of the brain shows all the activity. Anyone who has a storke destroying there left lobe with have to learn the right side of the brain to draw and it's toddler level ability at best.

Horses are thought of as left or right handed, determined by which way they bend more easily. About 99% of horses bend to the left more easily. They go around an arena or racetrack more easily counter clockwise. Because they find it easier to bring their left hind leg up under them (called carrying themselves as opposed to pushing with that leg). This is important in dressage/eventing. Get the horse to bend its stiff side and it will soften and bend its poll and jaw and seek the bit as it should. First thing you do is figure out which side needs to bend. You bend muscles the relaxes the mind, too. So left or right handed. Sort of.

From my experience volunteering at a rescue, parrots are usually left-footed. They grab and manipulate things much like a hand, and they do tend to prefer one foot over the other (more often their left foot).  Just thought I'd mention it, they too are bipedal like us and the kangaroo and since they're birds, they have a completely different evolutionary history, yet they also prefer one side over the other. It definitely suggests bipedalism has something to do with it.

Playing the guitar is a weird one when it comes to handedness. The less dominant hand is doing a lot of very precise work on the fretboard. It always seemed strange that it would require so much fine detail and precision from the "less controllable" side

Right handed or left handed are kind of oversimplifications. The vast majority of the population is right hand dominant, right arm dominant, right leg dominant, right eye dominant & counter-clockwise rotation dominant. The next most common thing is to be left hand dominant, left arm dominant, left leg dominant, left eye dominant & clockwise rotation dominant. However there is small segment of the population (including myself) that have split dominances. For example: I am right hand & right eye dominant but left arm & left leg dominant & clockwise rotation dominant.

My father raised holy hell with the nuns to admit me, where my left hand was whipped with a switch daily. As a medical practitioner it is generally accepted that right handedness come from the " fight or flight response". The heart is in the left side of the body therefore the left hand is needed more to defend it. The brain then adapts to keep the left hand closer to the body and the right farther. As most actions require "eye to hand coordination" the right hand is preferred as it isn't needed to defend the heart. So we evolved to to be right handed

I am ambi. So, I am equally dextrous. I did grow up right handed, because I could. I made the choice when I was very young after my older brother called left-handed people weird. No 5 year old wants to be weird. It was the worst decision I have ever made. When I was 41 I rediscovered my left hand. I started writing with it and the most amazing thing happened. My whole right side of my brain started tingling, and also the back, AND my whole left arm started tingling. Plus, my I.Q. jumped up and I developed savant skills. In reality I always had them,Soooo.....that one decision kept me from accessing my real abilities.    This should help explain the importance of handedness.  Jami*
My father was left handed.  When he started school in 1929, the teacher literally tied his left hand to his desk so he would have to use his right hand.  That was apparently a common practice a hundred years ago.  Dad developed a stutter in childhood which we all believe was caused by being forced to use his right hand.  To his last day, he had terrible handwriting.   By the way, his stutter vanished while he was serving as a signalman aboard a destroyer during WWII.

It's all about hips for me.  I'm right-handed and play many sports but I always main whichever hand is needed for my left foot to be forward such that power generation is a counter-clockwise hip rotation.  E.g. baseball: right-handed, disc golf: left handed.  (Same full lower-body and core motion, just different hand).  I think the eyes are also extremely important.  If you have far better sight in one eye than the other, you're a lot more likely to use whatever main hand that goes along with that eye (e.g. shooting a rifle).

I have changed my dominant eye from left to right. In fact for most of my life I couldn't even close my left eye to look through a scope, for example. I spent a day really focusing on doing this and eventually managed it, and now (from using a bow and a rifle, it has become automatic). When I do the test to see which eye I'm actually using, I find that its now my right eye (by holding up a finger etc). If I concentrate, I can make my left eye dominant in a matter of minutes, and then change it back to right. Its amazing what the brain can do. Unrelated to this, I eat and write with my left hand, and thats it. I've always found it easier than most to use my non-dominant side in certain sports, like kicking a football, for example. When I entered the military at 18, I was immediately trained to carry an object (like a briefcase or binder) in my left hand so my right hand was empty in order for me to be able to render a salute to an officer without switching the object to the other hand.  As a lefty, this was no problem since it was the way I would typically carry something anyway.  But then I started training as a military policeman (Security Police in the Air Force to be specific).  During that training, I was told not to carry things in my "gun hand."  This became a bit of a problem since if I was armed and carrying a pistol on my left side, I would be expected to carry an object (like a flashlight) in my right hand.  Yet, I would still be required to salute a commissioned officer with my right hand.  It was a bit of a challenge, but I remember making it work.  Lol.

So if I do 3000 damage I will write it with my fingers in the air. However if I write on a piece of paper I will use my left hand. So I am constantly using my left and right hands to right. I do this with a lot of things so anytime I am forced to use either hands they work about the same. When I was a kid in school when we played tennis I quickly move the paddle between my left and right hands depending on where the ball was going rather than use a backhand stroke.  I was able to beat everyone despite the teacher telling me I was wrong, I never changed it. I still play tennis that way today

My husband knew someone who was right-handed, but left master eyed, so when he used his air rifle, he had a crossover stock made.  Also, my husband is right-handed, but when using a catapult, he would pick it up with the right and draw with the left. He was very accurate. His mates were also right-handed, but did it opposite and thought he was left-handed.  Also, when my husband was young and had to use a 14lb sledgehammer  he would start off with the right side, then switch when fatigued. He could hit things just as accurate and hard left-handed, but when he asked anybody, to hold what he was hitting, they usually said, 'No'. .... They just couldn't understand that I could use both with equal force and accuracy.  He has been asked, numerous times, if he is left-handed when doing something physical, to which he has replied, 'Makes no difference mate, either suits me.'  For myself, I am right-handed, and I am a touch typist who has done data entry using the numeric keypad on the right. Simply for efficiency, I started using my left hand for the mouse and found it far more comfortable. I often got asked if I was left-handed.  Another observation both my husband and myself made was our dwarf hamsters. It seemed they favoured a particular pouch to store food, it first. We took one of them to the vet one day as she had managed to turn her right hand pouch inside out. They had to remove the pouch and give her antibiotics. We asked the vet if hamsters were like people with a bias to left or right, i.e. right pawed, so they used their left pouch first or visa-versa. The vet paused and said, 'You know, I've never thought about that before. That is an interesting point.' After her, 'pouchectomy', the little hamster still tried to pack a non-existent pouch.

I have to disagree with the teeth/scraping hide thing. You wouldnt scrape across the hide if you were holding it in your teeth. You would scrape down towards your left hand. Your mouth to your hand would be the only taught path to scrpe on. The rest of the hide would be loose. I would also be willing to suggest the scrapes could be early hygenic attempts, dye applications (meh, thered be dye), or from actual tool making. In fact I disagree with the whole premise that they fleshed a hide in their teeth. If they were smart enough to understand they needed to flesh the hide in the first place, theyd have layed it down on a rock or a log and worked over it... like we still do. They wouldnt have wasted energy and calories on the hard work of holding the hide off to their side in their teeth.

Growing up I used both of my hands pretty equally, but had overall weak hand strength. I cannot recall what it was diagnosed as in the 90's, but today it's called Sensory Processing Disorder (SPD). I was asked at 4 years old to choose a hand in order to recieve physical therapy to develop dexterity and strength. Unfortunately I chose my right hand, and now at 31 its been obvious for a long time I was a natural lefty, which tracks because several of my family members are.   Today the only true things I consistently do right handed is throw (for distance) and play guitar/bass. Everything else I do left handed. And considering my handwriting is atrocious, it truly doesn't matter which hand I use for that lol

Im not sure if this is true but I always linked hand dominance to eye dominance. Not many people know but everyone has an eye dominance as well. As an archery coach we always check a persons eye dominance before teaching to decide which hand they should shoot with. I noticed a lot of people who were left handed but right eye dominant did many other things in their life with their right hand because it made most sense according to their vision. (Ex writing with left but using a hockey stick with their right hand)
Then why is it that a guitar player who is right handed is performing the most complex hand operations with the left hand?  I propose that if the palm is facing down is performing the most complex operations, we attribute that to the person's handedness, but if the complex operations are performed when the palm is facing up the handedness is attributed to that of the opposite hand.

New Caledonian crows use sticks as tools in much more complicated ways than other crows.  Their eyes are even set up in a way to give them binocular vision where the tool is unlike other crows.  They do a lot of work with beak and one claw on the tools they modify, while standing on the other foot.  It seems like they have a preference for which foot is the tool using one and which is the standing one, but it could be because the tool is lying in one direction already in clips I watched or whatever.  It would be interesting to study that, if no one has.

To be clear, he's not saying that we are descended from chimps.  "Split from" or "diverged from" the way he's using it means that the line of Homo species which culminates in Homo Sapiens shares its most recent common anscestor with the Pan lineage which contains chimps, bonobos, and at least one mysterious unknown lost species that interbred with both.  In other words, the Homo and Pan lines are sister lines that diverged from a common ancestor, according to the current models.   In a family tree chart, chimps and bonobos wouldn't be our (H. Sapiens) father or brothers but our great great cousins, as multiple species of Homo developed before we get to H. Sapiens sapiens, and modern chimps didn't exist either at the time of the split.  [Edit:  I just noticed that Eons themselves made and pinned a comment saying the same thing.  Oh well, redundance is better than silence, I guess.]

Observing dogs, they seem left pawed, cats... right pawed (but my memory is not as clear for cat observations.)   I sailed with two left handers. Boats have a lot of tight awkward spaces and things always needed fixing.  We quickly figured out that some tasks were left handed and some right handed. We'd switch for different bolts and screws.  And if speed of reflexes was ever selected for, then absolutely there would be selection for a percentage of left handedness. You get ambushed, one left handed is probably all that is needed to defend the off side for the split second it takes the right handers to turn.  50% should be more easily selected for, so there must be some compelling reason for handedness. Might just be right handed brains just happened to evolve in a positive direction. Left handedness then evolved or remained in the DNA because of its unique contributions,. Like my ADHD.

Seems like there‚Äôs a lot of naive adaptationism in this piece once it gets to the persistence of left-handedness. Left-handedness could persist in a small population without it having any selective advantage at all. At the very least, videos like this should mention neutral evolution, founder effects and genetic drift as possible explanations for left-handedness. Also, what is the causal direction of right-handedness and the ‚Äútool-making‚Äù section of the brain? Did hominids become right-handed because that spot in the left-hemisphere evolved to support tool creation or did that spot in the left hemisphere evolve to suit tool creation because hominids became right-handed? And what about other tool-creating and using species like corvids, cephalopods and, indeed, chimpanzees, that don‚Äôt seem to show handedness?

About 40 years ago I worked at a company that made woodgrain trim for Jeep station wagons. It was bent by hand . I noticed that if a lefthanded person learned to make a part on one side of the car he could immediately make the same part for the other side. But a right handed person had to learn that side the same way as any other part.

Sorry, but you're wrong. We find our dominant side by falling to it in our formative years. It's ALL due to which leg is shortest, even if only by a minuscule amount. Toddlers can't hold their weight perfectly until they've learned to stand and walk confidently, and with every fall, they'll mostly fall onto their weaker, shorter leg side. The hand/arm which will invariably be closest to the ground and become stronger and more dominant as a result, is that closest hand.

You didn't mention that children are initially homolateral. They rock back and forth on all fours before they develop heterolateral crawling. Also, they try two-legged jumping forwards before they "get" the knack of alternate leg walking. This suggests a period of post-natal development when lateral preference is not genetically predetermined, and may develop from external conditioning and or chance. I know exactly why there are more right-handed in humans. It's a combination of genetic and natural section. If there were 50% right-handed and 50% left-handed in the beginning of our evolution, I'm certain that after every battle the survival rate for right-handed warriors are higher. Let's say that you are right-handed and I'm left-handed, and each of us stabs each other at once, my survival rate is lower than yours due to the fact that your sword finds my heart easier than mine does (your sword is naturally aiming at my heart). Just like that, there were less and less left-handed warriors to this day.
You got to it later, but the most rational reasoning consistent with human behavior and evolution towards communal, society living is more right handed humanoids killed more left. The women of those men had more children than the women with offspring from left handed. That was the natural selection.

Here's another explanation. The heart is slightly on the left of the chest, so from early times, Mothers held the baby in the left arm to soothe it with their heart beat, leaving the right arm free for activities like prepping raw food and cooking, braiding hair, body decorating with ochre etc  The survival of the infant is the most important thing, so evolution selects anything which contributes to it, & so right-handedness.
I am naturally left handed, but was taught to write with my right hand early in schooling. Never could grasp it as well as with my left but as an adult I am now left hand dominant for dexterous things like writing, painting, instruments but right hand dominant for strength based tasks like throwing, punching, lifting and my hobby rock climbing. It even extends to my feet where I can only kick a ball, or do high strength based rockclimbing moves with my right leg. I wonder if there is a level of nature vs nurture to hand dominance.
Funny story: i worked with a guy who applied for a grant from an organization that supports and recognizes left-handed people...he wrote out this multi-page essay about how he wasn't even left-handed and essentially just wrote this essay out of sheer boredome...  they ended up giving him the grant because....he literally was the only person to submit an essay for this grant!
You might be interested in how handedness has affected architecture. You will find that in medieval castles and other fortresses that have stairways , those stairways hug the walls such that upon ascending the walls are invariably on the right hand side.  This is because it inhibits the movements of right-handed invading swordsmen, giving the (also right handed) defender above an advantage with greater room to swing his sword. Now, a lefty attacking would nullify a lot of that advantage, but the defender would still have the height & weight advantage of striking downwards.

One thing that still surprises me is how engineers and designers still forget left handed people exist in the world. Tools for example can be made both handed but quite often are not with safety switches or on off switches for a right hander. Another example is a knife sharpener I own that has the knife dangerously close to my hand that holds it. A simple fix would have been to center the carbide instead of offsetting it. üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:00 üöÄ *The video explores a scenario with a giant circuit to question how long it takes for a light bulb to light up when a switch is closed.* 01:29 üîÑ *Unlike a battery, electricity in the grid is in the form of alternating current (AC), where electrons wiggle back and forth without a net movement. The traditional explanation involving continuous conducting wires and electron flow is challenged.* 03:26 üîç *James Clerk Maxwell's breakthrough in the 1860s revealed that light consists of oscillating electric and magnetic fields. John Henry Poynting's 1883 discovery of the Poynting vector showed how energy flows through these fields, challenging conventional views about electrons carrying energy.* 06:20 üåê *In a simple circuit with a battery and a light bulb, the energy flow is explained by the Poynting vector, showcasing that it's the electric and magnetic fields, not the electrons, that carry energy.* 08:51 ‚ö° *The video emphasizes that energy flux only goes one way, from the battery to the bulb, even though electrons move both ways. It highlights the misconception that people often think they're buying or pumping electrons.* 09:49 üîÑ *The analysis of alternating current (AC) is explained, demonstrating that even though the direction of current reverses, the Poynting vector consistently points from the source to the bulb.* 11:47 üåê *The historical failure of the first Trans-Atlantic cable in 1858 due to distorted signals revealed the importance of understanding energy transmission through electromagnetic fields, not just the flow of electrons in conductors.* 12:17 ‚ö° *The answer to the initial scenario is provided: the light bulb turns on almost instantaneously, and the limiting factor is the propagation of electric and magnetic fields through space, not the movement of electrons in the wires.* 13:50 ü§ñ *Cas√©ta by Lutron, the video sponsor, is introduced, offering smart lighting control that allows users to turn lights on/off with a phone, Alexa, or Google Assistant, enhancing everyday experiences with a deeper understanding of electrical energy flow.*  Made with HARPA AI

If you are right about the advantages of left handedness, wouldn't we expect to see a flipping between the predominance of  one hand over the other? As one becomes more common, the other increases in value and therefore will eventually surpass the former in selection bias. The idea that it would stop being selected for is odd as you have presented no advantages to being right handed so there would be no reason that that would always be the default. It seems more likely to me that the trait is neither universally advantageous or detrimental so there were no real pressures either way. In response to how "handedness" came about in the first place, we have an enormous amount of complex behavioral learning to do as children, perhaps this is  way of categorising aspects of tasks so as to more easily master them.

I am totally comfortable using either hand with knives, forks and spoons. I consider myself fully ambidextrous..

I think we don't have enough data. Right handedness really influences the way we interact with the world. When I was younger I used both hands predominately until a teacher made me stick to using just one. It made me lose a lot of the coordination I had with my right side. And although I can still write with my right hand, it's not nearly as good. I find myself using different hands for different activities like tool use. Many tools that I instinctively want to use with my left hand are not made to be used for my left hand so I adapt with my right. I believe there are probably a lot of people who deal with these issues and because the world is so right-centric people with left handedness start adapting to a right-handed world from infancy. I think we need to have better knowledge around these things for teachers and trades and I think if we acknowledge and encourage these differences from a young age it could create new levels of efficiency. I know for a fact I'm a faster electrician because I have adapted to use all my tools perfectly with both hands. I'm sure there are thousands of instances that would end up being more efficient if people honed their specific coordination from a young age.

I've sometimes thought that handedness developed as an expediency. We need to grab stuff with a hand so often that it's best to have a default idea of which hand to use, rather than having to decide in each situation. Imagine if each time you wanted to grab something you had to take a few milliseconds to think, "right or left?"  If you were fighting with someone who had already decided, he'd beat you every time. Why it's right i have no explanation for.

I had a library book about the brain and handedness once, and it said that research shows that we do various tasks with our right OR our left hand, and we do not know ahead of time which hand we will use for a certain task.  Sure, we pay attention to which hand we write with, but what hand do you use to tie your shoes?  To floss your teeth?  Me, I used to wear contact lenses, and I cleaned them with my right hand and inserted them with my left.  And I didn't notice for years that I was switching hands.  Handedness is over-rated.

Left-handed, grey-eyed, ginger woman here (apparently a rare critter, according to some, lol).  Since dominant forelimbs in mammals and other vertebrates was mentioned, here are observations regarding avians: they, too, appear to have a dominant foot. And, there's an indication that it impacts how they prefer to interact with humans (avians living in captivity).   I began observing this in avians kept as companion animals over the course of many years, and because they were the object of my interest, and I am left-handed, I wondered about them, too.   Nine species of parrot and one domesticated breed of duck later, I did notice patterns.  What I qualified as left/right dominant for each avian consisted of 2 distinct categories:  1) The preferred foot first extended for most activities, including stepping onto a human hand or arm, or holding and manipulating objects, like food. 2) The preferred human hand for interaction with each avian.  Because all the birds, with exception of the Pekin ducks (2 individuals) and 1 individual Cockatiel, American Budgerigar, and Scarlet macaw, respectively, lived with other humans prior to residing with me, and my right-handed spouse, this provided interesting results.   Most of the parrots exhibited a consistent and overwhelming use of dominant foot with stepping, holding, and defense (pushing another bird away, for example).  The next observation was interesting, because some of the birds had first lived with my right-handed spouse, and came to know me later, or vice versa.   The birds showed an absolute preference in terms of which hand we as humans offered food, a step up, or grooming and petting of their heads.   If we offered the "other" hand, the macaws, Senegal, 2 Budgerigars, and both ducks either hesitated, waited, or pushed our hand away (with ther bills), refusing our approach.   Switching our hand to match their dominant-sided foot proved notable, and I found out my right-handed spouse had noticed this before I'd discussed my own observations of the birds with him.   He found himself naturally switching hands to approach each bird to avoid "misinterpretation" by individual birds.   I myself had noted the same thing, and in discussing it, realized that the pstticines residing with us appeared to be largely Left-dominant in their own use of limbs.   We noted that both ducks, which were acquired at 3 days of age and imprinted on me, but also interacted with my spouse a great deal, showed the same preferences when we picked them up, petted them, swam with them, or gave treats.   While dominant foot in avians didn't seem surprising to us, the added element of requiring us as humans to use the "correct hand" to approach them added an additional layer of insight for us, since they were requiring us to adapt to their preference, regardless of our own hand-side dominance.     Below are my observations from journals and notes.  * = did not reside with other humans during lifetime  Pekin duck 1 - Left Pekin duck 2 - Right Cockatiel 1 - Left Cockatiel 2 - Right Budgerigar 1 - Left Budgerigar 2 - Left* Budgerigar 3 - Right Budgerigar 4 - Left  Budgerigar 5 - Left (disfigured legs and feet due to neglect and abuse) Budgerigar 6 - Right  Budgerigar 7 - Left  Scarlet macaw - Left* Blue & Gold macaw - Left  Senegal parrot - Left  Golden-capped conure - Right   Blue-crowned conure - Right Nanday Conure - Right Indian Ringneck parrot 1 - Right Indian Rigneck parrot 2 - Left

What is the evolutionary benefit of handedness?
Even dogs have handedness when shaking a paw, they'll predominantly use one over another. It's not so rare.
Humans and chimpanzees are both descended from an upright-walking ape. Knuckle-walking is an evolutionary adaptation from upright walking to move quickly through a tangled jungle without the risk of tripping over roots, stones or fallen branches. Human beings evolved on arid plains and retained the upright gait.

Maybe, instead of just waving that vague phrase "evolutionary advantage" around, it was simply the case that once our forelimbs were freed from walking (or swinging), they were no longer required by circumstance to be even-handed, and so went over to one side. Since there is equally no requirement for the lateralisation to be absolute, some left-handed people remain. Why lateralise at all? The universe itself is asymmetric. It just is that way.

I'm left-handed, my dad is left-handed and my son is also left-handed - so yeah, I can well believe there's a hereditary element to it. However, living in a predominantly right-handed world has forced me to adapt to some things with varying degrees of success. I actually can't use scissors left-handed at all, and I also use my right hand for computer mice. However, the latter REALLY messes me up for using graphics tablets where what you're drawing shows up on your computer screen but not the tablet itself, because I'm torn between two instincts; I draw, paint and write with my left hand, but I'm looking at the paper while I do that, whereas with a mouse I'm using my right hand but looking up at the screen. Trying to draw/paint with that kind of graphics software is an unholy alliance between those two things; my 'drawing hand' won't sync with looking up at the screen instead of down at the paper, but I don't have the necessary precision to draw anything with my 'mouse hand.' Needless to say, I have the coordination of a drunk chimpanzee whenever I try to create something from scratch. And don't even get me started on using cutlery when I'm eating..!

It's my experience that any "dominant hand skill" that you first learn with your non dominant hand, your dominant hand will automatically learn that skill.  I'm a welder of 30+ years, and I was advised by an old timer to first learn to weld with my non dominant hand, and sure enough, once I learned to weld with my left hand (non dominant, in my case), I could easily weld with my right.  Over the years I've become ambidextrous at pretty much everything.  It just seems like unlocking a part of the brain, and how you perceive your body.  For an opposite example, in boxing after learning technique in the mirror as a rightie, and watching my reverse image in the mirror, I easily transitioned to a lefty boxer after watching the lefty version of myself in the mirror for so many hours.  Switching to southpaw, my reflection was now a rightie, and having already learned stance, bobbing weaving, and punches/combinations as a rightie, it was easy to make my rightie reflection perform all of these techniques from a southpaw stance.  It's become so natural that I forget which stance I'm in, as me and my reflection just kind of become "one".  There were certain things as a rightie that I always naturally did left handed, such as shoot a bow and arrow, use a hockey stick, etc... perhaps I was somewhat randomly ambidextrous to begin with, so maybe that accounts for some of this.  I can also write left handed pretty easily, and can write backwards with my left very easily, but cannot write backwards with my right without concentrating on it.  I'm just so fascinating!  üòâ

I have a hypothesis that handedness is mostly directly tied to ocular dominance.  Mostly people are right-eye dominant and right-hand dominant. And it‚Äôs much easier to be same-side dominant rather than cross dominate, especially when using something like a blowgun, atlatl, spear, bow/arrow, or gun. People who are left-eye dominant and right-handed have a real hard time aiming guns accurately, for instance. People who are same-side dominate are going to be much better/more successful hunters. Thus, there‚Äôs evolutionary pressure to be same-side dominate.   So the more foundational question is - Why are most people right eye dominate?

Again, also just my experience only, but for me most horses are more reluctant to pick up their right-lead canter and more willing to pick up their left-lead canter. They also seem to bend easier to left, in general, than the right.

When I was young, there was a trend in Russian school system to "switch" lefties to write with the right hand. It was explained that usually lefties have bad posture when they are writing, and all that stuff. So I was "switched" from my dominant left hand to right, but it only made me truly ambidexterous, because, well, you can't just switch your brain like that. One comment seems to contradict evolutionary theory. If there is a trait that has an advantage, it should lead to more offspring having that trait and advantage, not less. Handedness leads to increased use and additional strength. Having muscles to handle speers is arguable important for human survival. If we look energy needs, we might observe that it requires more energy to build and maintain the same muscle strength in both arms, or that by using two hands equally, one doesn't develop the strength they would have by using one dominatly.  Using just one arm reduce energy needs of maintaining both arms to just one arm for maximum strength when striking or throwing, or ensures the most development and strength in at least one arm.   In short, bipedalisim allows us to carry tools, and carrying tools and weapons favored handedness with lateralation in the brain codeveloping.

A trait doesn't have to be advantageous ‚Äî evolution doesn't work like that. If it's advantageous it's more likely to stick around, and even become dominant. I'll save everyone some time by summing up the video. In the Stone Age, the few early humans who produced computer mice (made at the time of a rock shell, a spherical bone, and shale buttons) happened to be right-handed and thus mainly produced right-handed mice. Since left-handed people had trouble using these primitive mice and thus securing employment in the Stone Age's IT-centric job market, natural selection took its course and the number of left-handed individuals dwindled over time. üòî

8:15 On the phrasing ‚Äúlefties have evolutionary advantages‚Äù: This might have been true if ‚Äúleft handed people‚Äù was a sub-species of the human race, and left handedness was inherited by all individuals in that group. But, since it is randomly distributed, like the sex of a child, it is more probable that it has to do with the advantage of diversity for the human race as a whole.

I also wonder how much of a factor the periods of more recent history where left-hand dominance was demonized or suppressed has had on left-handedness overall. My dad was left-handed, and at school they tied his left arm to his body so he would be forced to use his right hand. This wasn't uncommon at the time and didn't raise any concern, where as the same treatment in a school in the same region today would be seen as barbaric.
There's also societal pressure.  Does anyone remember when lefties were discriminated against?  That they were occasionally even burned at the stake as witches or had the offending limb punitively removed.  In school a great grandfather of mine's left hand and arm was strapped to a plank which was tied to his side once the teachers realised he favoured his left hand.  The right handed students were allowed to use their both hands but he was only allowed to use one hand, his right hand, for anything.  That would certainly exert an evolutionary pressure against left handedness.

I wonder if it might be even more simple than this.  Way back I read a study on underwater births.  It said that in their study every one of the babies born in this way were bidextrous.  So, I'm wondering if the left vs right hand aspect is just whichever hand the brain determines will be most useful.  With the right hand often being the one picked since the parents are using their right hand and interact with the baby's right hand more than it's left after birth.    As for why humans would start using their right hand to interact with a newborn (whether they were left or right handed) could be a variety of reasons.  However, it could just be as simple as hygiene.   Though, more likely INDIRECT hygiene.   For example, we have to remember they didn't have toilet paper back then.  Whatever they wiped with probably didn't prevent their fingers from getting... um... dirty.  Some might even have used just their fingers.  I could see a group of people agreeing to use the same hand for this purpose so they always knew which hand was okay (not smelly/dirty) to allow others to interact with them with.  Basically more politeness than the concept of hygiene.  And the left hand just happened to be what they chose.  And other communities adopted the same over time.  And of course they would use the clean hand when interacting with the newborn.  And instinctively interact with the child's similar hand.  Within 1 generation you would have mostly right handed kids.  All speculation of course.  Would be interested to see a study done on it though.

One correction: In boxing, your dominant hand is actually less active. You "jab" with left hand all the time and surprise with your dominant hand|  the frustration of boxing with opposite handed opponent comes mostly from his stance. Instead of putting their left leg forward, they put their right leg forward, mirroring you. This disrupts the boxer who is used to position themselves against a regular opponent. Even southpaws themselves are used to fight against orthodox fighters and another southpaw disrupts their rhythm as well.
It also sounds to me that specializing into a handedness has the advantage of only requiring one hand to be "very precise", instead of requiring both hands to be equally useful. Maybe that saves some brain-space for other things.

I am a RN and I worked on a neurological unit for several years. Part of my patient population was stroke victims. One thing neurologists and neurosurgeons always note is the patients dominant hand which identified the patients dominant brain hemisphere. This is because if a person had a stroke that effects the non-dominant side of the brain, they have a higher percentage of recovery because the dominant side of the brain can take over for the damaged side. Now this is very simplified and there are many other factors, but it was always something that was noted in their records.

Fiddler Crabs are also handed, with one claw growing larger than the other and being used more often. if they lose their dominant claw, their remaining claw will grow larger to compensate, and when the other claw grows back, it stays small, effectively changing their handedness.

Leave it to egg headed "scientists" to make the reason so complicated.  It's pretty simple. When manipulating tools, each hand has to perform different tasks. One, basic clamping and stabilizing the work and the other, more complex control of tools to apply to the work. With eons of practice, our brains developed to do both tasks at the same time. Even though each manipulative task my be very different from that of the opposing hand.

I‚Äôm left handed. When I was 6 years old my year 1 teacher forced me to try and write right handed for that year. Apparently she thought left handed people were wrong. I‚Äôm now stronger right handed for mundane tasks; eating, throwing, kicking. However playing guitar and writing I still do left handed, when I do tasks which require more thought.
It is clearly obvious that being right handed or left handed comes from which part of the brain you tend to use in your daily task thinking. This has been shown many times in scientific studies. Left handed people tend to use the right side of the brain and right handed people use the left part of the brain.  If you study the old written languages you can discern that writing that flows from the 'right' side of the page to the left was invented by left handed people, this way as you write you can see what you are writing, this is the same for 'right' handed writing who write from the left to the right side of a page and allows the writer to see what they are writing. The hand would hide the writing if not designed in this way. Original Hebrew writing wrote from right to left (before it was changed) Arabic also writes from right to left, in fact the majority of the original languages wrote this way. Some wrote down the page so that both left and right handed people could write with equal performance. (Tibetan and early Chinise)

An easy way to establish your left/ right preference is the following: hold your finger up at arms length and align it with both eyes open with a subject behind it. Now close one eye alternatively. The eye where the alignment doesn't change is your dominant eye and in general your dominant half of your brain.

I have a spearhead from a Zulu warrior. I was going through the channels one day. On passing through had seen a show on spear hunters in the Serengeti. So I started watching the show. Two hunters were hunting a gazelle I believe. To tire the gazelle one hunter with a spear stayed stationary, spear in hand above his right shoulder. The guy, circling for the gazelle around on the right same position with the spear. Their left arm was folded in near their chest. To protect vital organs and their heart. In case the gazelle's horn strikes in an attack. So, right arm out stretched gives greater distance away from heart. To completely protect your heart with your right arm means you have to cross your arm over more, slightly limiting your left arm and torso in certain situations. Also in the way they hunted noticed they also read the hunting seen left to right as the gazelle was mainly off to the left of them. So gives the chance to more easily protect the heart and provide a killing strike.

I used to work with several different species of macaque nonhuman primates (monkeys) . I have to disagree.  Primates do show favortism to their right hand in greater frequency than their left hand. Seen best with new mothers carrying their young and during foraging. Though I do believe that primates do have a handedness, i can see how it may be more difficult to recognize because of the way they move around...i.e. swinging from branches and the classic gorilla walk.  Just observing their mobility would lead to a conclusion of nondominance.

This is all wrong. It's neuro -programming-conditioning. Mammals become left/right handed when they successfully utilize one of their apendages to complete a task. It is more likely that they become right handed because spatial relations operate from the left hemisphere of the brain, but they can scratch or grasp s/t with their left hand first causing a neurological imprint (if it works, they repeat that process, and their left/right becomes dominant). A right handed great ape doesn't have a slight or considerable survival advantage over a left handed ape.

Handedness is an expression of single eye dominance.  The advantage of strong single eye dominance is aiming. Thus a single human throwing a rock or sharp stick, can kill any other creature on Earth (even a Blue Whale, Ahab!) - something a tiger cannot do! It's what makes Humans the most efficient hunters on Earth and why you never see chimpanzees playing baseball...

can't agree on this. Bats are mostly right winged!  Ok there are a lot of bats in the Royal Botanical Gardens in Melbourne. They hang from trees (upside done of course) and when it gets warm fan themselves with one wing.  Noe the vast majority choose the right wing. There is the occasional leftie bat but not many. Perhaps the main reason that the majority are right handed stems from the fact that the vital organs are on the left side of the torso. So if our ancestors were to defend themselves from a threat, they would subconsciously position their vitals further from the threat and use the reach of the right hand with a tool like a spear or blade for defense.  And given that they use the right hand with defense they could also use it with general work/labor since they use it so often anyway.

In Archery, Eye Dominance is a big factor. You shoot a right or left handed bow based on your eye dominance. You could be a right handed person yet be left eye dominant and would need to shoot a left handed bow. However, most people who are right handed are right eyed dominant as most who are left handed are Left eye dominant.

It's rather simple. Human beings, still today in most places, wipe their behind with their left hand and eat with their right. This is why lefties are discouraged, and forced to use their right hand, in many societies.
Certainly, in sport or combat, left-handedness is an advantage, mostly due to its novelty to righthanders. However, the rest of life in a righthanded world, is definitely harder for lefthanders, and lefthanders tend to have statistically shorter lifespans due to misadventure in a righthanded world.

Just a thought, but if dominant handedness came after tool use, maybe it was to allow more people to use the same tools? If too many people were a mix of left and right handed, then separate tools could've had to have been made for each dominant hand, costing resources, time, and manpower. If everyone had the same dominant hand, then everyone could use the same tools, and instead of making tools for separate hands you could just make more of the same tool and improve on it.

Once our Ancestors Knuckle walked out onto the Plains . Firstly , we stopped brachiating and secondly we had to learn to STAND UP . A Savage period of Natural Selection came into play here . Development of the Fully Opposable Thumb , Proper Feet and an alteration to our Hip Joints . Since our Lower limbs were no longer an extra set of Hands a Separation of specialisation seems reasonable for our New , Nimbler Hands .

i wonder how much of the reduced lateralization in lefties is due to nurture/environment vs. nature. As a left-handed person, we grow up in an environment that has many things set up for right-handers, like a computer mouse. We end up learning to use those things with our right, while preferring other activities with our left, so the "load" ends up getting split more evenly.

In the use of the Leboyer Method of childbirth - giving birth in warm water and dim quiet environment - 102 out of 104 births resulted in the child being ambidextrous (equal ability in both left and right hands). It is believed that this is the result of the birth event being less traumatic for the child, causing both hemispheres of the brain to work equally. An environment that a modern hospital birth presents - bright lights, people shouting ‚Äúit‚Äôs a boy!, and the drastic change in temperature causes one of the brain‚Äôs hemispheres to experience trauma that causes it to not work as equally‚Ä¶

as a left handed person this video is fascinating lol
I am ambidextrous, I can tell that writing with each hand is not a perfect mirror of one another.  Since both hands are expected to write the words directed towards the right side, the controls to write with each hand are not mirrored.  In both hands the middle finger is responsible for writing the letters.  However, if you want to write with your right hand, your right thumb is the finger responsible for moving the writing forward in direction the right side, while the other fingers just hold working as support.  On another hand, if you want to write with your left hand, the controls are flipped, that is to say that the left thumb is only meant to hold as a support, while, instead, the other fingers are the ones responsible for moving the writing forward in direction the right side.

Personally, I think it's random which hand become the dominant one for the majority of humans, but I think having most people have the same handedness was selected for because it makes cooperative tool use tasks (eg, stripping a carcass together) easier. The advantages mentioned for lefties remind me a lot of the origins presented for left-twisting snail shells. A large majority of snails have shells that twist to the right, to the point where animals that develop specific adaptations to hunt them often show the same assymetry in their mouth parts.   There is however a subset of snails (including some whole species) which are left-twisting, and while this can make mating more difficult in cases where it is only isolated individuals, these snails undergo significantly less predation pressure from highly specialised predatory species, thus giving them a niche, but again only so long as most snails remain right-twisting to prevent a strategy of only attacking left-twisting individuals from being viable.

So what is the reason for right handedness? Heard mostly about how being left-handed is fine too(which is common knowledge) but nothing about why being right-handed is usefyul in stone age.
The real reason for the right-handed preference is, as suggested, due to the bilateral nature of the human brain. As Iain McGilchrist notes in his fine book, The Master and His Emissary, the left hemisphere (and thus the right hand, which is generally controlled by the left hemisphere in vertebrates) is more concerned with grasping, while the right hemisphere is more inclined to deal with novel stimuli. In fact, according to McGilchrist it is only the right hemisphere (what McGilchrist refers to as 'The Master') that attends to novelty. Functionally, I suspect the right hemisphere is multi-dimensional and therefore able to deal with the continous function that Time represesnts (as background, Time is an essential element of movement). Whereas the left hemisphere, which appears to be two-dimensional and discrete is much better at dealing with static relationships resulting in far greater precision - much like a Cartesian or two-dimensional map. Thus, precision is the domain of the left hemisphere (and typically the right hand), while immediacy in terms of our reaction to stimuli, such as a predator, is the domain of the right hemisphere. In short, the right hemisphere is concerned with our survival from predators, while the left hemisphere is focused on us gaining prey or food. This bilateral approach to cognition is the evolutionary result of vertebrates (placentia-based animals in particular) moving from the relatively static world of plants, to one involving movement - thus involving Time. This change occured over 500 million years ago. Language, and speech in particular, is typically the domain of the left hemisphere, as a concept or a word is essentially two-dimensional, as set out by a word's definition, i.e., its defnining characteristic, along with the magnitude or measurement associated with that characteristic which represents the second dimensional aspect of a concept. This latter development, the creation of concepts and thus 'thinking,' began to happen about 70,000 years ago, with language (which represents how we tag our conceptual abstractions) first being recorded about 5,000 years ago. In short, our tendency to right-handedness is a function of our evolutionary bilateral brain.

Favoring right or left is also seen in dogs. Researchers found this when looking at dogs tracking people. If the dog loses the scent it turns either left or right making a loop back to find the scent again. It turned out that individual dogs always turned in the same direction. They were either left or right turners. Also look at dogs when they play. Which paw is mostly used for whacking the counterpart or to get the attention of the owner/handler? This is the reason why I say Europe and all the countries that drive on the left side of the road are wrong especially with manual transmissions. The way they have it set up a person will have to do things like changing gears, adjusting radio or temp and stuff all with their non dominant hand.   . The way we do it, our left hand can be used to steady the wheel - a very simple task that doesn't require much dexterity. And our right hands are free to do all the other little things that need to be done from time to time while driving. And even if they keep the design of the cars like in the States there'd be the added challenge of oncoming traffic approaching the side of the car farthest from you. And its just easier to make sure there is enough space between oncoming traffic if it coming nearer to you. .   Usually I am very critical of the bass ackwards way we do things here in the States but driving on the right side of the road just makes more sense.  Seeing as how the automobile was invented here I wonder how all those other countries developed driving on the other side of the road?

Being left handed you often have to be ambidextorous. Most poeple don't realize this, but so many of our modern conveniences are shaped for right handed people. Zippers, keyboards, doors, coffee pots and my favourite example, scissors, are often made only with right handed people in mind and can be quite uncomfortable and awkward to use with your left hand, so a lot of us lefties learn to use our right hand for some stuff. Notable exception being a high school classmate of mine who used her left hand for everything and even had her computer mouse on the left side.

Lateralization of fine motor control of the hands may have been related to the emergence of technocomplexes, and not just lithic ones that leave fossils. If hominin groups had sharp-edged tools, they could have been crafting elaborate aritifacts with wood, fibers and rawhide, like the Croatian Neanderthal. There may be a link to the emergence of laterelized language, via precision gestures and close attention to hand movements and imitating hand movements for learning tool use and tool making from conspecifics. Even gestural protolanguage, for example ostensive teaching of skills and depictive reenactment of behaviors and scenes (like pantomime, but with a lot of accompanying vocalizations for emotional effect) may have been lateralized. If hominin communities later conventionalized somewhat-arbitrary (less iconic) gestures into a stable inheritable vocabulary, it would explain cumulative culture and the persistence of technological advances and increasingly language-mediated symbolic behaviors. This is just speculation now, but careful theory building along these lines could lead to falsifiable hypothesis that may be tested in a future where palaeoanthropology has more advanced techniques to anlayze bones, stones and genes. Our models of hominin evolution may need to go beyond strictly-gene-based natural selection, to some kind to gene-culture coevolution where inherited vocabularies transmit and modify regularities in social phenotypes, i.e. technocomplexes, symbolic behavior and language.

As a boxer of many, many years, just a slight clarification on the boxing segment, orthodox fighters (right handed) would more often be wary of most punches coming from their opponents left hand (your right side) if indeed you're fighting another orthodox fighter. The usually much less common, but more powerful hits, you'd expect from your opponents right hand (your left). But yes, fighting against southpaws (lefties) is quite an awkward experience. So much so that southpaws do not usually prefer to fight other southpaws haha. Any decent fighter would be primed to expect where punches are coming from by their opponent's stance though, so hopefully it wouldn't be all that much a surprise in the ring for you!
Im better with my right hand than with my left, but i think a lot of that is due to practice. I can draw with my left, and often switch without noticing, especially is im doing things that require 2 hands (like the dishes) or my hand gets tired doing something. But i was taught right handed by default, so i was actually somewhere in highschool when i first noticed. We were asked to do stuff left handed and amazingly everyone was SO much worse than me at it. Later people pointed stuff out to me like "you were using your right hand just now but randomly switched to your left". I just never really paid attention because it wasnt a handicap. What, if any, relationship exists between handedness and eye dominance? I, and my father are both right handed. We are both left eye dominant. Regarding the combat component of left handedness, you left something out. Not only is the right handed opponent less likely to have encountered a left handed one, but the left handed fighter is more likely to have encountered a right handed one. So the likelihood of encountering another left handed fighter is low, and is essentially a direct contest of strength. This would select for left handed fighters over time, because of their ability to win fights in a mostly right handed world.
I was meant to be lefty like my great aunts on dads side. But my mom refused, ...now i just suck with right hand üòû
While it is true that modern humans are bipedal, and the other great apes are not, bipedalism cannot be taken as a distinctive feature of Hominins. Why not? Because there is evidence of bipedalism in probable ancestors of all or some great apes, e.g. Pierolapithecus catalaunicus, 12 Mya, bipedal but living on the trees. It is likely that the said other great apes' somewhat more recent ancestors were bipedal but later developed quadrupedalism. Thus, let us forget about instantly assigning bipedalism as an exclusive and distinctive feature of Hominins.

Also to be noted, kangaroos lack a corpus callosum, the part in our brains that communicates between left and right hemispheres. So essentially, if the kangaroo does something with its left hand then the only way the right hemisphere comes to know about it is through external stimuli.

My hand dominance/preference depends on the task that I‚Äôm doing.  For example, I write, bat, putt and usually eat left-handed.  I use scissors/knives, throw, dribble, and play instruments right-handed.  With brushing teeth and hair, it‚Äôs mostly right but I also use my left.  With eating, I can also use a fork or spoon in my right hand.  Likewise, if I‚Äôm using an xacto knife, depending on what I‚Äôm cutting out, I might use my left hand.     Growing up, I didn‚Äôt know how to explain to my teachers that just because I write with my left hand doesn‚Äôt mean I do everything with my left hand.  I don‚Äôt want dull left-handed scissors.  Or when we were learning instruments and had these little guitar things, my music teacher was trying to have me hold it the left-handed way but that wasn‚Äôt comfortable for me.  I actually like that I play instruments right-handed as I don‚Äôt have to learn backwards or get a special left-handed instrument (I play violin and have a guitar).

Left handed  people have been observed to be some of the most immensely talented and intelligent people in the world.
Left handed people have a natural advantage in basketball as they like to challenge shots (predominately of right handers) with the hand on the same side of their body as the shooting hand.  A lot of right handers want to reach across their body to challenge shots but the lefty does it correctly without trying.  They also have an advantage on the offensive end because defenders are used to right handed shooters so will reach to the wrong side of the shooter out of instinct and often the lefty can get a clean look at a shot. This is easier to spot in High school age or younger where people haven't been coached proper technique.

Being right-handed, I learned to play guitar using my left hand to finger the notes (which is "normal"). Other stringed instruments are the same, that is, the left hand is typically used to finger the notes. It seems so natural when the technique is learned from the start. Occasionally, I will flip the guitar over and try to play the notes with my right hand. It's amusingly impossible. That "shows to go ya" (as my mother used to say) that any right-handed person can learn some amazing skills with their left hand.

My hypothesis :-  The very first division of the zygote is unequal in terms of mitochondrial distribution. since mitochondrial division is independent of the cell division , just before the very first division of the zygote,the mitochondria in the cytoplasm divides few times to increase its number..  the very first division of the zygote fails to distribute the mitochondria equally among the daughter cells.  the daughter cell which gets more mitochondria becomes more active due to more metabolic activity as compared to the other daughter cell which has a low no. of mitochondria.  this active daughter cell eventually becomes the right or left half of the body in the due course of development ,thus making a person right handed or left handed congenitally.

Heavier bone structure may not always show handedness. Consider the use of tools like shovels. The stronger arm is the one doing the lifting and the more agile arm doing the guiding. Strength doesn't always indicate handedness. My father grew up on a farm and I grew up hearing him tease me about his right hand being a trip to the hospital but his left was sudden death. He was a right handed person who had a more strength in his left arm due to scooping grain all day. His right hand guided the shovel while his left did the lifting. Food for thought.

Conversely, the lefty always meets righties on the court, and takes early advantage.  Baseball. left handed pitchers can be difficult for batters, for much the same reason, righties rarely meet one, thus the pitch can take early advantage of a batter, with how the ball spins, and curves at or away from them...  A lefty batter is 2 steps closer to first base..  it doesnt seem like much, but on a short hop hit, how many times have you seen the throw to first be very close...  now give the runner a 2 step advantage and its not close at all..  he's "SAFE"
My biggest quandary in being left handed is,  Id like to learn to play guitar.  There are three ways a lefty can learn guitar.  1. traditional left, restring a guitar, or buy a lefty guitar.  2.  Learn to play right handed, which some do.  3. Play a right handed strung guitar, upside down, and play as a lefty.  <<  Reason is, If/when I learn to play well, and at times end up at a place where there is a guitar, but not my lefty guitar, I could easily picky up a righty guitar and play...  not so fast if I learn to play traditional lefty. My guitar hero was left handed, Jimi Hendrix...  Her played a right handed guitar, turned upside down, strung for lefty.  Ive heard he could also play a right handed guitar, strung for a righty, upside down played as a lefty.

Since childhood I've had a Quaker Parrot that is decidedly left handed (footed? clawed?).  If you hand her anything like a Cheerio to eat, she will always grab it with her left foot.  Likewise she will always step onto your finger left leg first, and step off of it in the same manner.  When she was about 20 years old, she fell from a perch and broke her left leg in 3 places.  The vet said they didn't have much hope for her surviving the injury, but we gave her constant care and made sure her leg was always well bandaged and dry.  She made a full recovery and regained full use of her left leg which she still uses almost exclusively for any task.  I've never had another animal with a distinct preference for one side over the other but she was determined, even with a serious injury to continue using her dominant leg and the vet believes that it was her constant use of the leg after the bandages came off that allowed it to regain all of its strength.
Why posit that at one point all humans became right-handed and that left-hand use emerged later as "evolutionary advantage"? What is the reason and the basis for this absolutism, when variation is a stable characteristic of humans?

I think the reason we don't see a hand dominance in primates is because of the lack of large tool development for hunting.  I hypothize that because our hearts are on our left side, we dominated our heavy activities with our right hand.  People who use their left live on average 7 years less due to cardiac related breakdowns.  Due to this, it was better to be right handed to pass on your genes considering 7 year to someone who only lives for 35 is a lot longer of a time than for us now.  It's called survival of the fittest.

It's actually completely inaccurate to say that if some trait persists in the population at low levels, there must be some evolutionary advantage.  There just has to be no strong evolutionary disadvantage. The vast majority of humans have brown eyes, but that doesn't mean that there must be some evolutionary advantage to blue eyes for the trait to persist.  Look up "Hardy Weinberg equilibrium" for a discussion of this.

I'm a standard rightie until it comes to boxing, then, without conscious thought, I always face my opponent as a southpaw.  And whenever I fight another southpaw, I have this moment of confusion when I realise that they are also fighting in reverse.   After a lot of thought, I realised that my preference followed Bruce Lee's maxim: *Strongest weapon to the nearest target.* I box with the goal of using my dominant hand to strike the face in the shortest possible time.

Is mixed handedness a thing?  I write more fluently with my right, but can write left handed too, just at slower speed.  I play an irish flute with the hand positions reversed.  I hold a pool cue with my left, but my right is dominant for other physical things, such as archery - I'm a dead shot using my right to pull, but I can shoot by pulling with my left too, just not as accurate, but I think that's more an eye dominance thing.  When I use my left, it is much more intuitive, I don't "know" what to do, it's sort of making 100% accurate guesses.  When I use my right, I'm much more certain about the results.  I couldn't honestly call myself ambidexterous, but my brain seems to have trouble deciding which hand I should use for what and is kinda happy with either.

This doesn't make sense. It could be the other way around, meaning lateralization took place because most people preferred one hand consistently. Chicken or egg problem. I believe it's more likely that the teaching process caused the preference. Passing on your knowledge how to handle tools the learner would imitate the teacher, hence the rising number of one certain preferred hand usage. Eventually with a bigger population of humans on earth it would tilt the number of people using a prefered hand in either left or right direction, it could have been the left hand, but it turned out to be the right hand by chance.

In genetics i have learned that there is a gene for handedness. If the alleles for the gene is dominant then the person will be right handed and if both alleles recessive  then the person will be either left or right handed or a mixture- and that is determined randomly by how the individual happens to prefer and develop to do a specific activity with one side. That is why left handed people can have a preferred side for different tasks, but right handed people will do everything with a preference for the right side.
