But how does this relates to the fact we have the same FOOT preference as HAND preference? I will again point out that this seems to be overlooked by americans, because it's one thing that we really usually don¬¥t think about EXCEPT when playing football (soccer), as we usually DO NOT need our feet to perform fine motor skills.
It's interesting that the word in english is "left handed" or "right handed", demonstrating a correlation to HAND.  The words in portuguese, and I suppose in other latin based languages, is destro (right sided) and canhoto (left sided), although I think in other latin based languages left sided may be SINISTRO (sinister, which in latin meant left).   edit: in spanish the word for left handed is ZURDO (izquierda means left). In italian, being left handed is MANCINISMO, while the word left is SINISTRO.  I mention this specifically because the video barely mentions FEET. Because the creators are probably americans who give football a second thought.  However, when playing football, your foot preference is usually VERY VERY similar to your hand. Meaning... a strong right handed person will be a strong right footed person, someone who can use left and right hand the same way, will be similarly skillful with both feet, etc.   edit 2: it seems portuguese is alone in not talking about left HANDEDNESS or right HANDEDNESS. The article about HANDEDNESS in English has correspondents in Italian, French, German, Spanish, etc. But not in portuguese.  Portuguese has articles on DESTRO and CANHOTO, words that have no relation to HAND (in fact, the words for it also don¬¥t have relation to HAND in italian, spanish, etc)  But the portuguese article SPECIFICALLY mentions DESTRO and CANHOTO as individuals with preference of usage of LIMBS, not of hand.

Teaching golf has taught me that very clearly that when a golfer puts their Left Hand on the club, in what feels like a dominant position, that even when their Right Hand is also placed on the club, the brain is put into a mode that everything learned athletically over one's lifetime with the Right Hand is immediately overwhelmed by the brain allocating resources to the Left Hand - it's why all new golfer's slice the ball - that BA44 section of the Left Brain is turned off until you learn to put it back into control.

I have a theory.  It starts at the grocery store. Grocery stores are setup very specifically, because we humans naturally circle them counter clockwise. Starting from the right side and ending up on the left side.   What would a grocery store look like at the dawn of humanity? It would be trees, bushes, stoney cliff faces, and so on. What if we hung onto these surfaces for support? Getting even a minor injury from a fall back then could of been life altering. So it'd be very important to our ancestors to not fall and sprain their ankle. So being right handed was helpful because you'd be less likely to fall and get hurt. As the tree, bush, rocks, etc were always on our right side?

I'm one of 5 children. Both of my parents are right handed, but both myself and one of my brothers are left handed. Regarding the possible genetic link to handedness, I have a good number of left handed relatives on both sides of my family. On a slightly different subject, I perform a lot of tasks with my right hand due to many common tools are "ie. scissors, or any tool with an ergonomic grip or handle. Can openers are another example.  Finally, maybe other lefties can chime in, but in my experience, most lefties are more dexterous with their right hand than most right handers are with their left hands...
Maybe handedness is likely as the nash equilibrium in a system where behaviours can be taught to others by mirroring what they do.. I bet as soon as a handedness preference sets in, it becomes stable. Maybe the first human to stand upright picked up a stone, threw it with their right hand, a few others saw what they did and we've been right handed ever since. Offspring that had a bias towards the right hand would pick up skills better, become stronger and more agile with that hand, less likely to be socially ostracised, so all the pressure points to bipeds/tool users becoming handed.

Is it just me or is something off with the portrayal of tool use.  If I am using a sharp tool to scrap hide, why would I bring the tool towards my mouth?  The area you would be scraping would be from the left hand to the mouth not side to side.   Wouldn't it?   And you would scrape towards your left hand, who wants to hit them selves in the mouth as indicated by these examples?  Alternatively, could these marks be made by early versions of eating tools.  We know in recorded history that a knife was the most common tool for eating in early history.   And I seem to remember evidence of more primitive tools being used the same way.  Wouldn't that fit both hand use and how the marks are made better then what is being described here? My best friend growing up was a very rare ‚Äútrue ambidextrous‚Äù person. He was perfectly ambidextrous even at a young age, with full 100% even control with both hands and he did tons of studies growing up about it and showed that his brain was symmetrical, to an odd degree even beyond the average ambi person. He would often do demonstrations writing with both hands, but also capable of writing backwards with one of them, at the same time! It was weird and kinda cool.  Pretty neat. Castle towers were designed with spiral staircases that would favor a right-handed defender striking downward an invader coming up the stairs. They were made so it was very difficult for right handed soldiers coming up the stairs to use their weapons properly. This led to left-handed knights and soldiers being paid more for their ability to counter this and lead a charge up a spiral staircase effectively.
All this to say that we still don‚Äôt know what causes handedness?

One angle that they didn't poke at would be that handedness may have developed similar time to social roles. A tool maker would make tools to suit their hand preference, others who use said tools would have to hold it the same way to use it properly. In time this would lead to whole communities who prefer a set hand, as generations go on people would become further attuned to using a chosen hand. As trade and cultural drift happened a preferred hand for certain tools would spread and right won out over left.  Although I do wonder if more modern day items were available in left or right hand versions would we see a bump in lefties? is being right handed carved into most of out genes or are most people ambidextrous who grow up in a right handed world and adapt to right handed items leading to left hand coordination to atrophy in most people?

Interesting that color-blindness (8% in males) and left-handness (10-15%) are at a similar incidence.  Surprising an opponent in battle or seeing terrain/game/foilage a little differently than the rest of your tribe offers something unique and valuable.  Especially in humans which (essentially) only exist as a member of a tribe, not as solo animals.  The tribe is stronger if there is variety - near-sighted people to weave and knap flint, far-sighted people to spot game.  Cautious people who collect enough safe food for winter and rash individuals who kill the wooly rhino and that try that unknown red berry.

We are right handed because they made us right handed. Because when you are left handed, it activates the entire language center into your right brain. Excellent insight Mel. Yes, the denseness of the strong side can be felt when handling one leg of the horse compared to another. Yes, the handedness of the rider very much effects the lack of ambidexterity in the horse. We humans also are legged, using one leg more than another and consider the asymmetry of the spine in both athletes, too. We are always training for ambidexterity and balance, so when you get a left handed horse with a left handed rider it can be a challenge. I'm surprised they didn't mention how warriors would use shields with their left hands to protect their hearts. That evolved to combat formations where every soldier would use their right hand for weapons and left hand for shields. This detail is the primary reason why most humans are right handed, even though we are all technically ambidextrous.

I'm a lefty and I do well in boxing.  Crazy I didn't know this or think about it.
As someone that engages in sword fighting and is very near ambidextrous: the left handed advantage is more than just surprise. A righty that has only fought other righties has no strategies for dealing with a lefty. The sword is on the wrong side, the shield is on the wrong side. All the money shots that work on another righty go straight into the lefty's shield. In contrast, the lefty is well learned in fighting righties and knows how to exploit having the sword arm on the same side as their opponent. When two lefties fight, it is often comical, as neither really knows what to do.
I'd give my right arm to be ambidextrious
Stating that people have a dominant hand, like the right hand, disregards that for most tasks the two hands work together. For right-handers the left hand often holds and stabilizes an object. So the left hand tends to be more steady and have a firmer grip. See research by Yves Guiard on this.

Interestingly, molecules are also left and right handed.
Don't forget some individuals prefer their otherwise non-dominant hand for certain tasks! (I shoot pool lefty, it just doesn't feel natural the other way.)  Handedness is part of a greater pattern of lateral dominance that also includes the feet, eyes, and ears. People who skate usually stand on their left foot and push with their right; the opposite is called "goofy". And while a majority of people prefer their right eye for alignment tasks and peering into instruments, and a majority prefer their right ear for listening against surfaces or into seashells, cross dominance is fairly common, e.g. someone whose right hand and right foot are dominant but whose eye and/or ear preference is left, or vice versa.

I'm very surprised that you ommitted one of the strongest explanations of right-handedness, which is the appearance of speech and processing of speech in the left hemisphere of the brain.   This is clear when you observe hand gestures when people talk.  So we evolved a language, and as a result the right-handedness appeared.   Instead you focus in your video on dead-end explanations like genes, whereas there is a huge cultural component.  E.g. this paper: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14621511/#:~:text=Right%2Dhandedness%20may%20have%20arisen,the%20function%20of%20Broca's%20area.

I always assumed that handiness was tied to sleep position. Most right handed people sleep on their left side. If this happened over evolutionary development, perhaps the left side sleeping meant that the left lobe of the brain had a more consistent supply of blood. This side of the brain was more developed and because it controls the right side of the body, that too would benefit from higher brain development. When I was in the hospital in my youth, the nurse told me to sleep on my left side because of a gastric issue. She said the stomach was designed to relieve pressure best in that position. We have other organs that are on one side but not another, the heart while in the center of the chest has a larger left ventricle. More blood on that side from sleeping on the left? I just figured it was something to do with the way we slept.

In boxing, left handed fighters often have more problems with other left handed fighters.  A southpaw stance makes the most sense for left handed fighters and is less common than a conventional stance.  In other words most fighters are better at dealing with right handed fighters because there are more right handed training partners to work with making it a more familiar experience.  You are usually better off training to fight right handed fighters (left foot forward) because there's always more of them.

Ok then, why is BA44 in the left side of the brain?
I am very righthanded and rightfooted, and only a few certain things feel natural to me to do with my left hand and/or foot (often those things will at the same time feel unnatural to me to do with my right hand/foot).  I am so righthanded that when using a fork and knife, I will have the fork in my left and hold down the food, and the knife in my right to cut it (which I think is what you are mostly taught to do if you are a righty)... but putting the food in my mouth with the fork in my left hand feels awkward... it feels like I am just about to stab my self in the face with the fork when I do that. XD  So while I cut food with the fork in my left and knife in my right... when it is about time to actually put the food in my mouth, I put down the knife and transfer the fork to my right hand to put food into my mouth with my right instead. This is why I almost never just cut one piece of food and put it into my mouth... but rather cut several pieces befor I make the switch, some 3-6 pieces but often depends on what it is I am eating... so that I do not have to switch the knife and fork around every single time I cut the food. On occasions I will cut everything on my plate down to the right size befor I finally start to eat. XD  Some might here wonder why I don't then just use the knife in my left, and the fork stays in my right hand the entire time... and sure, that is the logical thing to do... but... trying to cut food with the knife in my left hand feels even more awkward to me than trying to put food in my mouth with the fork in my left. XD  I do know as well that when ever I am about to step up onto something, be it stairs, sidewalk, or what ever, it is almost always my right foot that I take the first step up with... even if I have to take a set of short steps beforehand to make sure my right is the first foot to step up. And the few times I have kicked a ball around in my life it is always my right that I kick with... trying to kick with my left just does not compute for my body and brain, it's like my brain throws up error messages when it tries to compute how my body is supposed to move and lean when you kick with the left. XD  With a few exeptions here and there, I seem to be pretty "un-bidextrous"... XD

Lefty here.  I'm not sure I buy the selection explanation of negative selection (which is usually selection against a temporary or permanent disfavored phenotype, not a situationally advantageous one).  According to the explanation, "leftyness" may have been an advantage, but it loses some advantage if there are more lefties around, so it stayed low in the population?  How does that work in with long-standing tenets such as survival of the fittest and the fit that survive will confer their heredities more frequently?  If any of that logic is to be believed, then the puzzle is missing a big piece as to how lefty might have become a disadvantage to put a brake on population frequency.  The advantage becomes common and thus less potent is not the same thing as a disadvantage.

This not true. I can tell you the truth though.  Most Humans are right dominated. It goes back to the reason that human bodies are asymmetric. You inherently posses slightly more muscle mass on the right, namely your right Diaphragm. Your stronger right Diaphragm means you're favoring it. The Diaphragms attach to your spine, this will overtime mean your lower spine shifts slightly to the right, which influences the positioning of your pelvis and ribcage, which in turn influences the muscles. Your right side will be more compressed and your musculature more dominant, therefore if you have a dominant hand, it'll most likely happen to be your right. Lefties are simply counterintuitive bec they favor the hand on their less dominant side.  There you go
In the video it is stated that other species don't really have a prefered side. If you look up photos of elephants on google, you will see that most of them have a big and a small tusk. This is because elephants have a prefered side; they use one tusk more than the other to dig

The argument at 7:45 makes no sense: "If too many people are left handed, the advantage (of surprising enemies in combat) dissapears." The advantage should not dissapear at a meager 5% of all people, but a gradually slowing increase till they make up close to 50% of all people. The fact that didn't happen, should mean there is also an undiscussed evolutionary benefit to being right handed, and I can imagine what that advantage might be: an enhanced ability to make tools, since the neurons required for it form new connections everytime we use tools with our right hand. I'm surprised the most simple and obvious answer is not mentioned. People are trained from birth to use their right hand because that's how their parents were trained. Sometimes people learn more with their left hand by chance or because they were forced to because of an injury to their left arm or hand. The latter case is much more likely and would explain the greater "lateralization" if the brain's of those people. They learned with their right first, then were forced to learn with their left. This is an obvious case of a positive feedback loop in my opinion. As culture spreads and people are born into those groups and cultures, more people are right handed and thus teach more people to be right handed.

i'm left handed for fine complicated tasks, and right handed for heavy tasks.
I played piano as a kid. You can literally hear the composer's handedness in piano music: often the left hand (controlling the lower notes) is moving around less and playing simpler patterns.
The tooth scratches are as much or even more likely to have come from cutting off small chunks of food from a larger source.  This technique has the food (meat, cattail rhizomes, etc) held between the teeth & one hand, while the other uses a stone or bone knife to cut across the food (or to scrape the starches out of the fibers & into the mouth).  Our ancestors scraped hides every so many days, yes, but all humans need to eat every single day.

üß¨üß¨üß¨üß¨üß¨üß¨  üòÉüëâBA44üëàü§™  üß¨üß¨üß¨üß¨üß¨üß¨
I I was involved in some research years ago while at University that studied the effect on performing a unique task with the dominant hand if you were only allowed to train with the non dominant hand.  The test was quite simple involving moving a stylus as rapidly and accurately as possible between two contact points.  The re were three groups; a control group who were tested at the beginning of the trial and then again at the end with no training; a group who were tested with their dominant hand and then trained with their dominant hand before being tested again and finally the group who were tested with their dominant hand then trained with their non dominant hand before being tested with their dominant hand.  There was some minor improvement with the first group due to task familiarity and a major improvement with the second group but the most interesting thing  was that the third group also improved significantly..

7:41 - "If too many people are left handed, the advantage disappears." - I'm sorry, that makes no sense from an evolutionary perspective. If being left handed is an evolutionary advantage, then individuals who are left-handed should pass on their genes more frequently, which would quickly make left-handedness as common as right handedness, trending toward a stable equilibrium of 50-50.

Out of interest,  you might find it interesting that house cats and some other "small" cats have been observed to consistently prefer one paw or the other for more complex tasks.  In the case of housecats is oddly enough the dominant "paw" appears to be roughly split down gender lines, though not entirely.   It's been observed by breeders, but actually only fairly recently been documented and studied officially.   There is also some indication of it in canids.    While some critics point out that it could be a learned behavior from association with us,   it's just as unlikely as handedness being a learned behavior in humans.   As research into animal intelligence  progresses, some things like  "Handedness" may not to turn out to be quite so unique to us, as we previously thought.    It's just not something commonly recorded, but it doesn't mean it isn't there.

I submit that another reason for the prevalence of right-handedness is the feedback loop: The world is full of right-handers. Thus, much of society is geared towards right-handedness. At some point, design decisions are made to make things safer, but if there is a parity involved in that decision, it will favor right-handed people. Consider scissors. Unless you buy special ones, they will be right-handed. This means that a left-handed person will be less dextrous (pun intended) when using them, and thus more prone to injury. It is a small and subtle example, but can add up over a whole society and population. I seem to recall hearing a statistic that left-handed people had a shorter reported lifespan. This is consistent with my hypothesis (though not evidentiary)

**Correlation is not causality.**  The fact that a particular part of the brain is active during a particular activity (whittling,...) does not necessarily mean that it is involved in that activity, in making that activity happen.  We don't know enough about the brain to make that kind of assertion.  "The evidence **suggests** the involvement of this part of the brain in this activity" might be better language.  "The right side of the brain controls the left side of the body" is similarly problematic; we don't actually know that; "seems to control" might be better.  We are afflicted with distorted, rather fanciful stories about the brain being "in control" of things; this causes problems.  Also -- **EONS videos are absolutely awesome!!! Thank you so much for making them!! I watch them all the time and love them **  :-) :-)

I strated out with both hands as a kid but gradually shifted to the right because it was easier to use tools I was working with. Most things are created with the use of the right hand in mind for sure. I still used both hands simultaneously though, so I can write, cut, ect with my left hand just fine. I always feared breaking my arm so I intentionally  and naturally used my left hand to make sure the right wouldn't dominate.
In college, and for eight years after, I was a competitive fencer.  My coach told me that among highly ranked foil fencers, almost half were left handed.  In fencing,  the weapon is used entirely by the dominant hand, while the other hand is used only for balance.  Other martial arts are not as affected by prefered use of the dominant hand.

I am aware of another species with a right-handed favoritism...parrots.  The theory is the speech center of the brain is in the left hemisphere.  As language evolved more resources were dedicated to the left hemisphere resulting in a bias toward the right hand (which includes right foot.)  The theory of left-handers having an advantage in males (combat) makes sense as well.  It reminds me of the Evolutionary Stable Strategy.  The left-handedness only remains an advantage (combat)  if it is a minority strategy.

Interesting explanations but I feel like this might be over thinkng the problem. Keep in mind many cultures stigmatize southpaws (after all people wipe themselves with that hand) and even ways in which we teach people how to use objects have strong right handed biases. My left handed mom was "corrected" by her teacher when learning how to write. So toss in a stigma that just happened to arise, the fact that things that have grips that are shaped for the right hand, and the fact that right handed parents and teachers might not have the patience (and may strongly believe in anti-lefthanded bias) in for adjusting their grips and lefties and ambidextrous people just learn to self suppress this trait. People can learn and strengthen their non dominant hand. Rafael Nadal writes with his right hand and is a natural righty, but outright learned how to play tennis on his left side. We also see this a lot with baseball players many of whom can learn to be switch hitters or will throw with their right hands but bat with their left.

Generic drift, which is a stochastic factor, must also be considered. Not all traits are consistently selected upon. Left handedness can be a result from this drift, there don't have to be advantages for a small fraction of the population to possess it. But very interesting still!

I found out about body adaptation during a life in a video about a dig that found the body of an early Olympian, shown on some unbroken vases. He had legs bones 50% larger than normal, an enormously over grown and developed right arm socket with longer right arm bones and a mostly fused spine due to lost intervertebral discs causing vertebrae to join together. These abnormalities were due to his (short, mid to early 40's) life long pursuit of 3 sports, marathon running, discus throwing and chariot racing. The larger leg muscles required for marathon running required larger bones, the overdeveloped right arm and socket to support the wear and tear of discus thrown and the fused spine from the damage due to the vibration of chariot racing.

Also, fussy babies tend to calm better when held on the left. All 7 of my nephews and nieces have preferred me holding them with my left arm (it was a theory I read about 15 years ago, so it seemed liked a cool and harmless experiment to do as I never let them be fussy for very long and ensured they didn‚Äôt need changing/feeding etc, and if they didn‚Äôt settle in my right arm I‚Äôd switch arms) and even their parents got involved when I explained and they all noticed an improvement in every baby. It worked on all of them up until they could steadily walk on their own, and a few of them still prefer left sided cuddles to right sided cuddles even though they are all 7+ now. The original theory I read said something like the babies calm easier with a stronger heartbeat sound, and that right handedness may have occurred as a direct result of babies being held in the left arm while other tasks were being done, while other species‚Äô babies tend to either walk very quickly, or have a very strong grip reflex to hold on to their parents without hindering the parents hand usage

I've always wondered about your handness translating across the rest of your body. I've always heard that most people who are right handed will also prefer their right foot, eye, and ear (and vice versa for left handed people), but I'm not like that at all......I'm completely right handed (and not ambidextrous at all) but I kick left footed, favor my left foot to push off when running, favor my right foot to push off to jump, favor my right eye (like for looking through a telescope) and favor my left ear for like talking on the phone. I guess it's called cross dominance except in my case it's everything except handness.

I do everything left handed now. Its amazing to me how the brain and body adapts.

They state that humans are the only mammal with a preference for one side.  Anyone who works with horses, doing any higher level of dressage type work, knows that while most humans are right handed, most horses are left "handed" ... meaning that when moving around a small circle (~20 meters), most horses are much more supple, more balanced, more comfortable when turning to the left.  Its very unusual for a horse to be equally comfortable in both directions. They definitely have a "handedness" ... probably other animals do as well, but it would be hard to recognize if not working so closely with them.
The heart is located on the left of the body, so opposite you, another human's heart is in the path of your right hand. Makes sense that you would want to apply a straight force into their body, instead of across. It's because we wipe with our left. Duh
I find it really hard to believe that the marks on their teeth were caused by "slipping" stone tools. A hominid had to be fairly smart to process animal skins into leather and to also to sew such leather into garments (create bone needles, and thread needles with perhaps sinew). It's likely that any "slipping" of the stone scraper (a tool that was pretty sharp) would have caused injury to the gums or lips. A smart hominid would have quickly learned to (a) not scrape in that direction anymore (ie. upwards towards the mouth and teeth), and (b) to pass on that information to whomever they were teaching (like a child). As early as they were, I doubt they were stupid enough to continue "scraping" their teeth in the same manner of injury over and over. There has to be another explaination of the marks on thier teeth such as eating hard nuts and seeds, perhaps gnawing bones and  maybe breaking them with teeth to get at the protein rich marrow, or cleaning teeth. For all we know, it could have been a practice of a tribe to clean the flesh off a skull (and keep it) of an enemy or deceased tribe member (maybe a death ritual) with stone tools, thereby causeing marks on the teeth. Marks could also have been caused by natural processes on the skull and teeth, not long after death, such as sharp rocks coming in contact.

The video is titled ‚ÄòHow humans became (mostly) right handed‚Äô but it never gives a solid theory. How about this one. The right side of the brain that controls the left side of the body thinks more in abstract, which is why artist and people in professions which require abstract and creative thought tend to be left handed. The left side of the brain that controls the right side of the body thinks more logical and organizational. So, with this in mind, once we started inventing tools and weapons and also using organized hunting methods the left brain/right handed became the preferred mates due to their success. Due to natural selection we became mostly right handed.

0:39 "But today no other placental mammal that we know of prefers one side of the body so consistently." Sea Otters (Enhydra lutris) are in the order of Carnivora and are placental mammals. They have skin flaps under their arms that they use like pouches to store stones and shellfish for later use. The vast majority of Sea Otters, although having two such pouches on either side of their body, prefer to use the left side flap (found dead sea otters mostly only have things in the left side pouch). Also discarded shells found around rocks that they lay mussels again to bash with their favored stone mostly have the impact marks on the right side. We have about as much evidence for the predominant right handedness of E. lutris than we do for H. neanderthals. Moreover seeing it in Sea Otters helps to confirm our intuition about how to interpret similar looking evidence in extinct animals.  There are a lot of differences between us and Sea Otters. So why we both have a predominant right handed preference might seem like something of a mystery. But there is a major similarity in our tool usage. Not that we both use tools (plenty of animals do that). But that we both keep tools with us for when we are not using them. Given that, I think there could be something about not discarding tools after use, but storing them on ones person, that in part can lead to a handedness preference.
4:38 but why ya boy got the swaggy haircut?... üòÇüòÇ
Haven't watched this yet but my prediction is its all about tool use.  Someone made a tool and for whatever random reason favored using it with their right hand.  Maybe it was a weapon made from a branch and the curve of the branch where they held it contoured more for the right hand so the user had a better grip with the right hand and so that is what they used and eventually favored.  This person made more of these tools which he choose to fit his right hand since thats what he was accustomed to and therefore others who used these tools also found that they had better control in their right hand.  As time goes on more people use tools made by those who were already accustomed to using them in their right hands.  Inevitably as a result if there is any genetic predisposition to using your right or left hand as dominant then those who were predisposed to being right handed had a slight advantage over the left handers as most of the tools and weapons were designed for them.  Likewise left handers had a slight disadvantage where everything related to tools or weapons was just a little harder for them.  Again inevitably this would have cause a slightly lower chance for those lefties to live long enough to pass on their genes resulting in both a technological and biological predisposition towards right handed people.  Personally I am right handed but I am also ambidextrous.  I can do anything with my left hand as comfortably as I can with my right but that was only through years of intentional practice.  Still I greatly favor my right hand in most precision tasks simply because thats what the tools were designed for.

I just came to a possible reason for this handedness.   Well, since there was not an (possible) answer to this question, I decided to give it a try and come up with something  possible - possible enough to start a conversation.  Thesis: When lying on our left side, our right arm is then free to move/use.   Assuming body similarities with our ancestors might not been that different, maybe they also had a preference when sleeping, resting and lying down.  Because of science, we now believe sleeping on our left side have more benefits than sleeping on the right side, digestion and health-wise. And assuming the body had at least the same level of communication/connection/influence over our thoughts, feelings and intuition, it is possible to imagine that our ancestors may have intuited this as well, therefore preferred the left side during their rest time on caves/shelter. Following this vague idea, I can imagine a point where the right hand became more skilled, just by manipulating its surroundings while relaxing.  What do you guys think. I'm just being creative :)

This theory has been largely debunked, I can suggest to read : MacNeilage et al. (2009). Origins of the left and right brain; humans are far from being the only ones with a lateralized brain and with right/left hemisphere behavioral bias, current theory has it that right-handedness rather emerged from a left-hemisphere specialization for routine activities (right hemisphere = unexpected events) , and that human-specific cognitive abilities (like language or complex tool-making) did not arise from right-handedness as there is also strong evidence for crows outperforming children (up to 7 yo) at tool-making while they lack hands --> they rather arose from a complex compound of ecological factors

"they began to wonder about two things" I think you mean tooth things
Being the brain protected by the skull, the fastest way to kill someone with a primitive weapon is damaging his heart. Being right handed allows us to hold weapons in this hand and put forward the right side of our body, leaving the left side behind and protected.  This vital organ can be further protected by holding a shield in the left hand. This predisposition certainly gave a evolutionary advantage. Otherwise, in small proportion, being left handed can also be advantageous, confusing adversaries who expect the attack coming from the right hand. A related and more relevant question would be why the heart is on the left side. Since animals appear to have this organic disposition as well, right handedness is probably a consequence of this.
Possible factor as to why there is a small but distinct number of left handed males. In martial combat left handers have a distinct advantage against right handers. Ah, they cover this later in the video.

From experience I can say that natural southpaws are a nightmare to fight from the orthodox stance but converted southpaws a lot less so (right-handed fighters fighting from the southpaw stance). That said natural southpaws converted to fight in the orthodox stance are also very difficult, style wise that is, because their leading strikes (nearest the opponent) are given with their dominant hand and therefore are usually well-timed, accurate and powerful.

One big difference between us and chimps is we can throw overhead. Our shoulders are fundamentally different. Now if we were hunting with overhead throws of rocks, sticks, spears etc. we get back to square #1 , that is that the better at acquiring food you are the better you are at raising a successful family and you will teach your successful hunting skills to the next generation. Others in your tribe will copy your success , mimicking your actions perhaps even down to which hand you use.  It is possible that was  the case, and if so you pass a skill along over a million generations that is learned my visual observation and mimicry you could argue that you should expect similar hand use possibly to the point that dominance becomes genetic.

Left-handed people represent about 10% of the world's population.  I ambidextrous as were my mother and her father.  Ambidextrous people represent 1% of the world's population.  Many people are ambidextrous in many ways but can't use their dominant hand for writing, detailed work, etc.   My grandfather, mother, one of her brothers, and I were completely ambidextrous, writing, drawing, painting, etc.  That said, I shoot a gun left-handed because I am left eye dominant, not because of anything to do with my hands.  My grandfather, mother and one of her three brothers and I are were all left eye dominant and ambidextrous. My mom's sister and two of her brothers were right eyes dominant and right-handed as was my grandmother.   My dad's grandparents, parents, sisters, brother, nieces, nephews, and that entire side of the family never had a left-handed or ambidextrous member from my great grandparents down.

I'm a righty but my main sparring partner is a lefty.  I can certainly attest to the fact that it gave him a huge leg up against most people because his style was so different.  However, since I trained with him all the time I was used to it and he lacked the surprise advantage against me.  I did, however, have to omit some moves from my repertoire that worked great against other righties but didn't work against him because I couldn't mirror it.  This included one of my favorites (something I blended from both Aikido and Boxing) that in our larger group was kind of seen as my signature move for a while but I couldn't use against him.  He expressed annoyance that he couldn't get to practice a counter against it, but from my perspective the fact that he was a lefty was taking one of my best moves out of my toolkit.

I'm thinking about what caused the mutation in the first place, maybe the asymmetrical place of the heart irrigates blood easier or with more nutrients to the left side with a minor difference but still enough to make a small impact on the development of the brain and thus prioritizing the tasks which takes the best path possible. I don't know, I'm not a biologist, I'm a psychologist. Greetings from M√©xico.
My theory is that left handed people were community tool makers, and would produce mostly right handed tools for their community. However due to necessity of economics, the quality of such tools were of inferior quality to specialized or personal tools which they would produce for themselves. The ability to build personal tools of superior quality, and by extent holding these objectively better well crafted tools, gave tool makers more renown and respect within the community which directly led to more successful mating practices (evolutionary fitness). Full disclosure, I am biased AF (left handed and have picked up mirror writing pretty easily).

I was explaining to my grandson why our motor skills have a smart side and a not as smart side. It has to do with our ability to use language. Processing sounds and visual symbols for language need to be quick and extensive. This works best if this process is concentrated in one of the brain hemispheres. The side that is dominant for language is not as good at motor skills. This tradeoff seems to be good of survival.

I have always been hardcore ambidextrous. When I was learning to write in school I would start with my left hand and then switch to my right hand about half way across the page. My teacher made me choose so I write with my right hand now. I still do everything else with both hands and it has always been an advantage for me, mostly in sports. People when they notice always ask when they see me switch hands while eating, preparing food, throwing and doing things like that.

7:26 im sorry. but I cant accept the hypothesis that the reason why an advantage was NOT naturally selected because it WAS an advantage and if it became popular then it wouldnt be an advantage any longer in a population. how does that even work?  "Im sorry, you have to die right now even though you have an survival advantage above others because if you were allowed to survive, your advantage will dilute the advantage of others thus making everyone less likely to survive".  Its like the very opposite of the theory of natural selection. Now if there was evidence that handed-ness changed from left to right thoughout history because of that minority advantage, that would be different.

I jump with my left leg, taking my first step usually with my left leg and prefer to start a sprint with my left leg. While I prefer punching with my right hand, I can punch with my left just as good. I can also use a knife and a fork to eat with either hand but lately I found myself holding the knife with my left hand more than the right. This one however I got to be left handed because I am right handed. It's not that I can cut with a knife with my left hand, it's that it's harder for me using a fork with my left hand which is how an avarage right handed person uses it. Because it's harder for me to use a fork with my left hand, I had to learn cutting with my left. I can't use both a knife and a fork with one hand...

My little brother was starting to prefer left hand (my mum's a leftie) but I intervened, he's a rightie now. What if a dominant hand evolved as 50/50 (left/right), with lefties having an advantage in fighting and righties in other non-violent motor skills. Then as civilisation evolved away from violence the percentage of lefties decreased to the percentage we see today. I'm right-handed but I think I became semi-ambidextrous by playing lots of musical instruments from a young age, especially the cello (where the left hand is used for precise finger placement). Though I do write/draw with my right hand, I do most other "fine" motor skills with my left hand (e.g. eating, handling my phone, threading a needle, tying knots, brushing teeth) and most "rough" skills that require more strength with my right hand. I don't really have a preference for many other things like catching, using scissors, opening doors, holding objects, etc.

Has anybody actually tried to use their opposite hand for a long enough period to see if we can willingly switch preference over time?   Humans learn by copying others so if most people were using their right hand then it makes sense that most would copy and use their right as a child thus leading to a preference for the right hand, it also makes sense that a small percentage would go against the grain and copy with their left as a child leading to the small percentage of left handedness we see today.  My point is perhaps our brains or biology have nothing to do with and it's simply a learned behaviour and we are over thinking it.  I mean what would happen if we took a baby and had it be raised in an environment where it could only interact with left handed people, would the baby develop a preference for the right or left?

As someone who grew up cross-dominant, I've had moments in my life where I had to consciously think about what hand to use for certain actions. I never use both hands for the same activity, but use different hands for different activities (I only write with my right hand and only throw with my left hand, I cannot throw with my right hand). I use to think it was weird that I would even have to think about what hand I prefer, when everyone else just simply knows, but now I like to think of it as a cool skill. Apparently, this skill of mine also means that my brain processes information more slowly then others, but I like to think about the fact that I have the freedom to choose what side of my body to use on any new activity I do. How many people can say that??  Not that anyone cares about any of this, but this video got my excited about the topic and I wanted to write what I was feeling :)

There is probably some natural selection going on that snowballed this.  Imagine a right handed father had two sons, one left handed, one right handed.  It would be much easier for the right-handed son to learn and mimic the father rather than the left handed son.  In a physical world of hunting and near-death encounters, that probably caused the right handed children to prosper and have a better likely-hood to breed.   As we became more civilized and the world was less reliant on hunting and physical survival, that natural selection is now less than before.

Great, informative video - thank you.   I wonder if it's an accurate observation that the concept of handedness or dominant hand actually applies more (or even strictly) to the wrist and forearm, and the types of actions they perform, than it does the actual hand and/or fingers.  Or that hands and fingers don't actually show dominance preference or tendency except through use, accompanying the dominant arm and wrist in activities where they are favored.  As I'm typing this on my keyboard,  I don't feel or perceive either hand or set of fingers as stronger and more capable; they're like mirrors of each other, doing the same task with equal ease, neither being favored.  But for this activity my wrists and arms are not as involved in the primary task.  Same thing for my son on his video game controller.  Different story for swinging a tennis racket, shifting gears on a car or throwing darts, where it's mostly arm and wrist; my favoritism and preference would be much more obvious and important to me.  I first wondered this from experience as and observation of stringed instrument players.  A right handed person will usually choose or be given a guitar that puts his/her left side on the neck, in charge of gripping those nasty barre chords and dancing across the frets for a solo (hand and finger stuff).  The right side is in charge of strumming and picking (forearm and wrist stuff).  Violins, violas, cellos etc are the pretty well the same, holding a bow instead of a pick.   Left handed beginners will be given a left-handed guitar, where the arrangement is reversed, but the same idea applies.   It kinda seems like the dominant hand (arm/wrist) is being purposely put in the place that requires greater accuracy and dominance in movement of the wrist and arm, over hand and fingers.  Sooo I'm right-handed, but am I left-fingered?   lol    In this context my left hand and fingers are way more dominant, dexterous and nimble than their right counterparts.  But then I can fairly easily picture training my right hand and fingers to do what the left ones are doing now.   I've tried playing left-handed guitars and the right hand is slow and clumsy, sure, but certainly able to make the chords and finger the notes.  Maybe it's fairer to say I'm equal-fingered, as demonstrated on the keyboard?      But man-o-man !!  Not a frickn chance in heck trying to make my left arm and wrist do the intricate strumming and picking that the right ones are doing.  Not even slow and clumsy; not at all.  Not a frickn chance.  My brain simply can't control them that well; they won't willingly move the way I want them to; they're weak and sloppy, my timing is non-existent and I keep missing the strings I'm trying to pluck   lol.    These observations make me think it's all about wrist and arm, and that's where the "handedness" shows itself.  The hands and fingers taken by themselves, certainly seem equally matched and not affected by it.  This is only my mind watching and wondering  :)      I'd certainly love to be corrected or find out for sure.  lol.   Thanks

As a lefty, when I wrestled in high school, I always noticed my dominant left side clashing with my opponents dominant right side. Like a mirror. it would throw off a poorly trained opponent who lacked defensive muscle memory on his right.
As a lefty, I've always been told by righties that I exist only "to do the Devil's work".  But really, I'm a mutt.  I use my left hand preferentially for general use and precision work, including writing.  However, in other aspects, my handedness is what I was taught.  I'm a righty in boxing, baseball, football, tennis, slinging, and spear-throwing because I was taught to punch, throw, kick, and swing the bat in those activities by righties.  I throw knives, grenades, and other objects quite well with both hands, and also fence with foils, epees, and longswords with both hands, perhaps slightly better with the left, because I taught those skills to myself.  And I'm pretty ambi in basketball and soccer because you have to be ambi to play those games.  And I really wanted to play guitar left-handed as it felt more natural but was forced to play it right-handed by a rightiy.  So it could well be that that once enough of our ancestors survived long enough to teach the weapons, writing, and musical skills needed for survival to the upcoming generation, any initial bias towards right-handedness got amplified by most teachers being righties.

As I was growing up, I always considered myself left handed, because I wrote and ate left handed. Then as I got into sports, I threw and batted right handed, and I would kick a ball with my right foot.  As I tried more sports and other activities, like playing pool (left handed), shooting a bow or slingshot (right handed), shooting a rifle or pistol (left handed), and the latest sport I started in my 40s, tennis (left handed), I realized I am partially ambidextrous (if that's the right term).  I got into martial arts at 18, and my first instructor was big on always practicing in both left and right handed stances. That has led me to splitting almost everything I do during the day between doing it left and right handed as equally as I can. I figure it helps keep me as balanced as possible.  The biggest issue I have had with my left handedness is when I write:  1) In a spiral notebook (spirals always in the way) 2) On clipboards with the pen attached to the right side (you have to drag the chain across the clipboard) 3) And the biggest pain is slow drying ink. Getting the ink smudged on your hand as you are writing is not fun. It messes up what you are writing, and you have to clean your hand every time you finish.

You are partially wrong about hide-scraping.  When held taught, the hide is scraped in-line with the stretched part, not across it. (The grip and bite holds are shifted each scrape to cover the hide similar to plowing a field or even how a tv works)  So this is why the marks are on the teeth.  They scraped towards (or away) the teeth and occasionally got a little over-zealous about it and scraped all the way to the end.  I bet they cut their gripping-fingers as often as their teeth.

Some commenters have pointed out that we say "after our lineage split with chimpanzees," "members of our lineage after the split with chimpanzees," and "after our split from chimpanzees" at various points in this episode. Just to clear things up, humans and our extinct relatives share a common ancestor with chimpanzees and their extinct relatives. After our lineage split from this common ancestor, we call our group "hominins." Living chimpanzees also have their own separate evolutionary history since that shared common ancestor.

Fun fact: The reason why left-handed people are nicknamed "southpaws" is because of baseball. Back in the day, they'd build ballparks so that the pitcher would be facing west when he was on the mound. That way, the sun wouldn't be in his eyes.

Fun fact: The description isn't entirely true. There are, in fact, other mammals that prefer one side of the body as consistently as us - if not more so. Polar bears, for example, are almost universally left-handed.

I noticed the 'handedness' in fighting while I was learning Judo. In my home dojo we learned how to fight with both a left-handed and a right-handed style and were encouraged to pracitce both evenly so you could switch it up in competition to mess with your opponent. Then I went overseas for a while and the dojo I trained at there taught lefties how to fight left-handed and righties how to fight right-handed, with no real encouragement to switch it up with a focus on perfecting your specific skillset as a fighter. It was weird at first fighting good left-handed fighters who wouldn't shift grip to fight on their weaker side. I got my ass kicked hard until I learned not to leave openings a left-handed fighter could take advantage on, then somehow between ass-kickings I learned some of the ways lefties leave themselves open when going for their preferred throws against a right-handed fighter. One phrase I can still remember is 'The bruise looks worse than it is, I'm fine' XD

Finally something that I myself thought about for a while :) Since among humans it was males who historically did most of the hunting and fighting, perhaps it is not so surprising that males have more lefties (surprise factor for the enemy). And that bipedal animals have a preference perhaps could be understand from a control theory (industrial variant) perspective: if the legs are already specialized for locomotion, leaving the hands free to other tasks, further specialization of the hands may confer the advantage of simplifying the control and communication system required to do things (as each side do just a subset of the tasks). It may spare energy for other functions (more brainpower, better immune system, etc). Nature is very keen on energy efficiency.

Fly fishing is a non-interactive sport, but it has interesting "handedness" implications.  Fly fishers mostly walk upstream, casting to specific fishy spots.  Generally, spots to the left are easier for right handers to cast accurately to, across their body.  In most cases, the fisher can turn their body slightly and overcome this, but there are a few spots on every trout stream, because of the action of the current or a tree branch in the way, that are super awkward for righties (or lefties on the other side) calling for a back-handed cast that can work but is hard.  On popular heavily fished catch-and-release rivers, right handed fishermen learn to try to make that awkward cast, because the trout living there might be less "educated" with far fewer people being able to perfectly present a fly there.  Lefties don't bother; they can ignore their awkward spots and not miss much; righties fish those spots all the time, so lefties can focus on "their" comfortable natural spots and catch fish.    I am a little bit ambidextrous.  I am mostly not good with my hands; I like to say I'm ambidextrous in that I'm equally inept with both hands.  But fly casting is one of my few skills, and on the trout stream, I can deftly switch the fly rod to my left hand (it's not like a golf club or baseball glove) and thread my fly right in there, on either side.  It might be my only evolutionary advantage.
Being left handed in a right handed world means forced ambidexterity. I wonder what my life would have been like on a planet of lefties!

I have a theory about this. The dominance of right handedness can be attributed to the heart being on the left side of the chest. In a confrontation with another hominid, the tool-using individual is more likely to defeat (kill) the other person if the strike lands in or near the area of the heart, causing more damage to the tissues carrying blood to the body. This trait led to more hominids using tools to defend themselves winning altercations, be it war or self defense, or territorial disputes. The left handed person used trickery or traps to win battles, relying on cunning to win battles instead of shot placement. Many people use traps to catch animals to this day. Right handed hominids would be more likely to kill an animal if they hit on the side of the main body with the heart. This could have led to us developing the traits associated with left and right handedness. Also, I trained in mma, and we were taught to lead with our power hand, and this could be interpreted at first as being in a southpaw stance, but it is not. The stronger hand, and as shown by the video, upper arm, is used to lead the attack/defense, due to it being stronger, and more capable if placed closer to the opponent. The entire opponent's body is a target, and my entire body is my weapon.

5:56 I'm wondering: if having a hand preference is linked to bipedalism, might it be because there would have been an intermediate 'tripedal' stage? I could imagine a sort of primate that would still need to have one arm on the ground for stability, while having the other arm free to use tools, make gestures, or carry things. If such tripedalism has evolutionary benefit, it could drive the development of preferring one arm for stability, and the other for tool usage.

I suspect the specialization goes down to "muscle memory" as well. Training both "sides" to some independent task takes extra time and effort that generally isn't worth it compared to putting more effort into mastering it with one hand. So humans basically *have* to specialize in one side or the other;  people who can ambidextrously master something are incredibly rare. And since animals generally don't do complex tasks involving one side of their body, the need to specialize isn't there.  ETA: I think you can even see this with some non-dominant hand tasks. For something like gaming (one hand on WASD, one on mouse), where you have both hands doing independent things, your off-hand will be better at its job than your dominant hand. Despite being right handed, there are things my left hand can do better, and if I try to do a two handed task 'backwards', my right hand is likely to be just as bad at the left hands job as the left is to be at the right's.

I think that the fact that we are mostly right handed could happen just naturaly... Here's how...  Say a million years ago, 1 person is right handed... He has kids and his kids are right handed... They too have kids and so on... So in the millions of years that passed, all the other people's kids at some point didn't provide any more offspring, but our right handed guy's kids did, so at some point a huge amount of the population of a curtain area, as astounding as it might sound, was predominately right handed simply because of that... Scale this up to all around the world and all our millions of years of evolution, and you have your answer.

I do consider myself right-handed, but I do certain things with my left hand which feels more natural. I only write or draw with my right hand, so that's why I would consider myself right-handed, however, I have cross-eye dominance, so my left eye is my dominant eye, and therefore if I'm doing something like archery, I have an advantage because my left eye is more in line with my point of aim since you draw back with your stronger hand. But if I'm doing something like shooting a rifle or a 2 handed gun, I shoot left-handed because if I were to shoot right-handed I cannot focus on what I'm aiming at without squinting or closing my left eye, and at this point, doing it left-handed feels more natural. I can shoot a pistol with either hand equally well, but even so I tend to favor my left hand for the same reason. This also leaves my right hand free to manipulate other objects with greater dexterity. Overall, my left hand is weaker in terms of doing certain physical things, but not by much.  I would be interested to know what causes you to have a dominant eye (I understand that it's because your eyes have different focal lengths, but why should this be the case?), and why it is sometime (but not often) your opposite eye to your main hand.

I have questions about this video content: 1. Why would an early human be moving a sharp stone so close to their face that a slip would smack a tooth? 2. Why would an early human slip of hand move their tool toward an object *to the side* and not further in the direction of motion (as shown)?  3. How on earth is that wet, floppy hide (not held in a frame) sufficiently rigid to scrape from side to side when the two points of tension are top and bottom?  There is plenty of support for handedness that doesn't invoke such flimsy evidence.

I am both left and right handed, depending on the task. After many years I've discovered that left is my precision side, and right my strength. I write with the left, throw darts with the left, but throw bigger or heavier objects, like a baseball, or a punch, with the right. With the legs kind of the same. I kick with the right, but stand on a skateboard like a goofy (lefty). Here's the funny part though. When I play tennis, I play as a right handed player (right hand holding the base of the racket), and my back hand is double handed, so in that case, I hold my racket in the exact same way I hold a baseball bat or a hockey stick, yet with these two last, holding them that way makes me a left handed player.

I think handedness must have arisen from interacting with other people. The vid discusses fighting, but then gives reasons that lefties would have advantages. I want to go back to the original example of scraping hides, with people working together.  If four people work together on a hide, they can each grab a leg of it with one hand, and wield a scraper with their other hand. The hide is stretched tight, and nobody hits themself in the teeth. The trick is to avoid hitting each other in the hand with the scrapers.  If all four workers hold the hide with their left hand, and scrape with their right, they avoid collisions. They can all fit together around a smaller hide.  (I'm thinking of my left-handed cousin at a crowded dinner table, so communal eating may also be an influence.)  We know that hide-scraping was a thing, and that going solo was a punch in the teeth. Cooperative hide-scraping would have led to conversational skills improving, also.  (I said something about holding the legs of the hide. I think a rock or two in the hand could aid in gripping the edge of a wet hide.)
Ironically, it's been shown that left-handed fighters are just as weak to other left-handed fighters as right-handed fighters, because they also fight mostly left-handers. But in gyms with a left-handed fighter, right-handed fighters are better at dealing with left-handers, because the left-hander is the only person in the gym who doesn't get to train against the left-hander. There are also many right-handed fighters who train left-handed fighting to switch stances and further confuse their opponents. Despite being right-handed, Nick Diaz actually PREFERS a left-handed stance, which totally changes how he fights. Many fighters have found themselves chipped away by his unexpectedly powerful lead jabs, which the majority of fighters (who lead with their off-hand) use primarily for finding range and setting up openings rather than a true weapon.

Amateur kickboxer here, and yes people who fight southpaw (lefties) are notoriously annoying to spar with. We are actually being taught now to try and be comfortable in both stances in case we encounter southpaw fighters in a match.
Handedness could be the natural conclusion of needing precision hand movement at all. Training two hands at precise motion results in two half-trained hands. Evolution would favour individuals who consistently reproduce accuracy and muscle memory unlike ambidextrous kids who double practice handwriting only to arrive at the same result at best but quite often worse. Lefties also have consistently poor handwriting and not just in left-to-right languages and ambidextrous kids are more likely to be dyslexic. A lot of language processing happens on the left side of the rain so favouring use of the right side or neither of the brain could be expected to do that.

I once knew this fellow who studied at a Music Conservatoruim. While his main instrument was the Clarinet, he also played the piano (this was an obligatory instrument, regardless of which other instrument you study), and the guitar. The thing is, he was actually left-handed, and as such had his own guitar stringed for left-hand use, but he could pick up a right-hand guitar and play it with the same ease as his left-hand guitar. In fact, he could play any guitar with equal ease with both his left AND his right hand, regardless of how it was stringed.

I write with my left hand, but use scissors, knives, and most other hand tools with my right. I think a lot of the reason right handedness is so dominant is that there are many tools (scissors of course, but guns, guitars, and golf clubs are more examples) that are manufactured to go a certain way. When you take people who are basically "neutral" and could favor either hand, and give them these tools without thinking about it, it's not terribly surprising even the "neutrals" would favor their right hand. I know that's why I favor one hand over the other in many cases, being one of those mostly-ambidextrous people.

Most Moms hold their babies in the left arm the reason suggested for this is because Mom‚Äôs left side is where her heart is & by holding her baby in this way  it is positioned closest to the comforting sound of her heartbeat. As baby holding must have begun concomitantly with the transition to bipedalism patently it began pretty early in our original bipedal ancestor.  Now consider a number of other factors - as holding one‚Äôs young in one‚Äôs left arm leaves only the right hand to perform pretty much EVERYTHING one has to do to survive & thrive - including tool making & tool use - it would seem that these factors make for a very robust case for handedness having evolved under precisely this maternal-holding-her-helpless-neonate selective regime. Further, also consider the fact that right throughout the mammalian order  mothers in 98% of instances are the parent who teaches &/or protectively oversees each new generation learning whatever they have to learn in order to survive & thrive. Including language & including tool manufacture & use. Girls have significantly better verbal & fine muscle coordination than boys.... When you blokes spar with one another & stride out on the hunt, you are merely taking what your ancestral Moms gave you eons ago, to a slightly greater post pubertal level than us girls, who stay home & get on with the really important job of bearing, raising & teaching our young. just saying .....

_H. heidelbergensis_ WAS NOT the last common ancestor of _H sapiens_ and _H neanderthalensis_  The common ancestor was hundreds of thousands of years farther back in time. Heidelbergs were on the Neanderthal branch, probably after the last common ancestor of Neaderthals and Denisovans. It appears they were sort of early, "primitive" Neanderthals.
As a lefty I'm grateful to live in a time and region where being left-handed is not seen as something bad and lefties are not forced to use the right hand. Met people who were forced to use their right hand which had lots of problems because of this (using your non-dominant hand can cause dyslexia, not being able to focus on tasks for a longer time, depression, etc). I wonder how neanderthals and early homo sapiens viewed lefties and when the change to seeing lefties as bad came.  Being quite left ond the handiness-spectrum using tools with my right hand makes my stomach hurt because it just feels so wrong. I wonder, if our ancestors often used their teeth as a thrid hand to hold things they were working on, couldn't we find evidence for handedness in the jawbone? If we clench something between our teeth, and then pull on it with our left hand, we exert a force on our jaw forward, down and slightly to the left. Done consistenly enough with one hand, this should result in a subtly asymetrical deformation of the lower jaw bone.  Edit: Just ocured to me, that if you are right-handed, you will probably use your right hand more often to eat, and if you tear off a piece of tough meat, you'd exert a force to the right. So, in a tool using person, the two (eating and working) might cancel each others out. But not necessarily. It could also tell us if handedness predates tool use.
I practice Japanese martial arts as a swordsman. I was told by our Senseis (teachers), we all hold our swords right handed whether we are right or left handed because our heart (vulnerable target) is on the left side of our body. Holding the sword right handed and facing our opponent from the right side shields our heart further away from danger- with the right side of our body. I believe this might contribute to the predominance of right handedness.

Title should be, more about why most living things have side preference, mostly right.  The pole beans in my garden, all twist right. Snails twist right, except for Jeremy, and his gf. One in a million. Lodgepole pine, and Douglas fir, start life with a left spiral, pass through zero at mid life, then twist hard right, as they get real old. I'm right handed. However, since the muscles on my upper right hand used to get sore from writing, when my office was computerised, I decided I would use my left hand for the mouse. I don't use a left handed mouse; I just use the right handed mouse with my left hand. The advantage of this is that I don't have to change handed when changing from keying to mousing (if that's a word). It is such an efficient system, I consider everyone should follow it. It also means that a skill has been developed for my non-dominant hand.

As a person who is fully ambidextrous, I've always been fascinated by handedness. My father told me that when I was first learning to write, I'd write half-way across the page with my left hand first, then hand-off in the middle and finish writing with my right hand. To this day I still eat the food on the left half of my plate with my left hand, then pass the fork to my right to eat the food on that side.  Interesting thing #1: Back in Jr. High I was sitting around the table in the caf with my group of 9 close friends. I was surprised I hadn't noticed it before, but as I looked around the table at everyone eating, EVERYONE at the table was eating with their left hands. My whole cliq was a bunch of lefties!  Interesting thing #2: My cat is left-handed.  Interesting thing #3: My older brother is the only person on both sides of the family who is strictly left-handed, all the cousins included. My father and I are the only two ambis. Everyone else is a bunch of righties.  Interesting thing #4: I do have a few odd specializations. When I write on a horizontal surface, I tend to go at it first left-handed when not otherwise prevented. When I write on a vertical surface (chalkboard/whiteboard), my preference shifts to my right.

Theory: the rise of tool use led to better (evolutionary) fitness from right handers. One group, early on after the split with chimpanzees, made tools for predominantly right-handed individuals, and thus they could be more easily used by other right-handed individuals: for the generations, right handed tools became the default and thus right-handed people could more easily use them and be able to survive to reproduce. Heck, we still see certain tools today that are overwhelmingly designed for right handed people (scissors and computer mice spring to mind immediately, although scissors do have left-handed variants and, while I haven't seen any explicitly left-handed gaming computer mice, I'm sure that the rise in symmetric designs for general use mice is more than just a design fad).

It's a bit of a trope in fencing that left-handed opponents are harder to cope with than righties. Most of the time you train with right-handed trainers, so you don't learn how to adjust when the attacks are coming from the opposite side.  Fortunately for me, an assistant coach on my fencing team was a lefty, and I got lots of practice.

Believe it or not dogs show hand preference too.  Ask anyone who participates in Flyball Racing.  One of the first things we do when we get a new dog to train is see which turning preference they have.  This gives the dog a speed advantage when they retrieve the ball from the box.    While it's been years since I've had any dogs with the right stuff to race, I believe that it's probably a 50/50 split.  I never took any numbers back then, but that's what it seemed like.  If you want some hard numbers you can do some research at tournaments whenever we're allowed to do them again  FYI the 2 that I raced were both lefties.  My current, non sports dog is also a lefty.  I've also had 2 herders that preferred to heel livestock from the left if given the chance, but my neighbor's corgi heels on the right.  Again I'm just reporting my personal observation, so don't take my small study size results as fact.
If any physiologists/anthropologists would be interested in a realtime study population, I can suggest one* for you. As an adult lefty, I've been subjected to countless inconveniences and a few distinct advantages. I have become naturally more aware of people's "Handedness" than most folks, and can tell you that I have never, ever, seen such a concentration of Left-Handed People as I encountered while spending a year (2006) working in *Buena Vista, Chaffee County, Colorado.

Interesting point about combative sports. I was a fencer in college and fenced left handed. Something like 85% of world champion fencers are lefties. And I can say from experience that righties HATE fencing a lefty because everything is "backwards" and attacks are harder to parry
Not that I know anything but I (am guessing &) feel that the heart being on the left side (>99% of the time) _probably_ has a large role in affecting & making the right hand the dominant hand a far more advantageous evolutional development. Stressing the muscles by the heart at all may affect the part of the brain that is associated with the autonomous function of the heart; thus the brain should, for evolutional advantages, optimize to make use of the right hand since there are less nerves associated with the right chest area.

Significantly more than half of all people are right-eye dominant. Visual dominance isn't something you consciously control, and there may be a strong association between right-hand preference to go along with right-eye dominance -- such as in throwing weapons, reaching to grab things, using bows and arrows, and many military weapons are definitely designed to be used right-handed only. Through evolutionary eons this preference might become more fixed.

There's enough misunderstanding about how selective pressure works that I feel it's important to point this out: left-handedness does not need to provide any advantage to keep existing, it just needs to not be a reproductive _disadvantage._  When you really break it down, traits are never selected for, only selected against.
Left handedness might just not be enough of a detriment to be totally bred out.
The former Soviet Union trained almost all their hockey players to play left-handed. Most Canadian hockey players play left-handed even though they are right-hand dominant otherwise.

Interestingly the benefit of left-handedness in combat is attested through history, as well. A gladiator being left-handed was considered a strong advantage to have.
Left-handedness may not be genetic at all, with no evolutionary component.  21% of twins are left-handed, compared to 10% of the general population.  Based on this, scientists studying left-handedness think that it occurs when a zygote splits, creating a mirror zygote that is left-handed.  The non-twin left-handed population probably absorbed their twin in the womb, a very common occurrence. Related, it's likely that a much, much larger percentage of the population are "chimeras" than currently thought.  A chimera is a person with more than one set of DNA in their bodies (but not in their cells).  They occur when they merge with their twin, and officially they are a portion of the population too small to measure.  However, bone marrow transplants and other medical procedures are starting to uncover more and more chimeras, so scientists suspect that the only reason they seem so rare is that we only take genetic samples from a few types of tissue.  Any portion of a person can be chimeric, so to find out for sure we would have to take samples from basically every organ.  Chimerism would also explain how people get genetic "mismatches," like different color hair on different parts of their body, or eye colors that don't normally occur with a given hair color, like brown-eyed gingers.

Being a lefty, I've picked up a lot of interesting trivia about people like me, including the fact that many lefties can write backwards very legibly (Leonardo da Vinci was famous for keeping his diary this way). Once I discovered I could that that, I tried another experiment and found something very cool. I can put a pen in each hand, then write the same text with both hands - but writing backwards with my left hand and forwards with my right hand. By using my left hand as a sort of guide, I can write much more legibly with my right hand. I'm curious to know how many other lefties can do this. I know I'm not the only one because I saw a video once that mentioned it as a rare lefty trait.

That claim about meeting left handed people in fights is total nonsense. Handedness is a learned attribute. Basically you start out even, and as you start doing more and more hand tasks, over time one hand becomes the hand that new tasks are learned with just as a matter of habit. Eventually, you reach a point where using the other hand starts to feel awkward because it lacks the familiarity with the base movements that the dominant hand has developed. When you add tools into the mix, there is a clear bias towards  right handed because tools have essentially always been right handed .  Lefties end up as lefties because they met with less societal pressure, eg writing in a notebook or with ink. When they finally met with enough pressure to recognize that being a lefty sucks in modern society, the perceived gap in motor skills was deemed to great to overcome.
Gorillas and Chimpanzees are right handed at the same rate as humans

People like tennis players are not the only ones to have asymmetric body development. People who greatly relied on the bow , such as hunters an military archers. have an asymmetric body development. This is because when using the bow the left arm is under compression when the bow is drawn while the right arm is under tension from pulling the bowstring back. Archaeologists have used this knowledge when excavating human skeletons.
