Thanks for the handy information!
Other mammals do have "handedness". Horses are definitely a species which do. Although their brain is wired up very differently to a humans and they have to be taught to accept new things on both sides of their bodies, when it comes to handedness, you see it when you are training at even a low level. Horses prefer and move more easily on one lead as opposed to the other. As training progresses we have to train more on the less dominant side, to have a horse that moves just as easily on both leads.   I've found the same with dogs when doing high level agility training or working rehab. So I'm sure it's present in many more species, but because we aren't training them at such high levels, the handedness is not as noticeable for routine tasks.
3:08  Such power
Very interesting video. Most humans are left leg dominant too. Preferring to climb stairs with right foot and also stepping down a height with right foot first. This could be due to position and structure of Human heart to Left side with a separate artery for left side of brain called Left common carotid artery that originates directly from the aortic arch and right side is supplied by a carotid artery that arises from a common brachiocephalic artery. Thus making Left side of brain more oxygenated than Right and making it the dominant side. And as left side of brain controls the right sided limbs, the right sided limbs became more dominant and evolution did the rest of the job perfecting it.

Telling left from right is actually a surprisingly difficult task, as (unlike up and down, which can be tested by dropping an object) there is no objective measure of leftness vs rightness.  For this reason we have a specific region of the brain that plays a key role in distinguishing left and right. This is known as the "angular gyrus" and it sits in the parietal lobe. Damage to this region (for example in a stroke) leads to something called Gerstmann Syndrome which, amongst other things, causes patients to lose their sense of left and right!

7:38 Could you run that past me again. If too many people are left handed, the physical advantage disappears? For the longest time, I've always considered myself to be left-handed. I've always told people that I'm left-handed. One day, I started really thinking about it, and I came to the realization that I do many more things right-handed than I do left-handed.   In fact, there's only 2 things I do left-handed, and that is write and eat. Everything else is right-handed. This does make it easier to cut my steak too when I eat. Most everyone cuts with their dominant hand, and then switches the fork to their dominant hand to eat what they just cut. I cut food with my right hand while holding it still with my left hand, and then just pick it up with the fork in my left hand to eat!  Also another interesting fact: When I shoot guns (rifles or pistols), I shoulder and fire right-handed, but I'm left-eye dominant, so I aim with my left eye when shooting a pistol. It's impossible to do this with a rifle, but I am able to aim with my right eye accurately. I had a perfect score in my weapons training in the military when qualifying.

Something I have often wondered is if there is any evidence of other species throughout history selecting mates in a similar way to how we humans do today, by which I mean that survival of the fittest doesn't necessarily seem to be a primary factor anymore. I imagine this isn't really something that can be insinuated through the fossil record, and if anything it would be more easily studied in the behaviour of living animals as opposed to extinct ones, but at this point human pairings aren't always about fitness. Our perception of love can drive us to connect with people on a level beyond physical/mental/emotional fitness and instead through similar likes, passions and aspirations.   I guess when it comes to something that might be discernible in the fossil record, is there any evidence of how human mating practices have changed through the years? Were we initially generally monogamous and with advancing consciousness became more promiscuous? Have we always been willing to procreate with numerous different members of our species? Did our sexual practices vary i.e. some members of the species were promiscuous, others mated for life? Is there any evidence to suggest if the young of our ancestors were raised by parents or by a larger troupe such as with some modern great apes?

Can you all please stop ignoring science for racism. This channel always shows ancient humans and Neanderthals with "white" physical features. There us no evidence that Neanderthals had light skin. There is major evidence that they were brown/black skinned. The physical features associated with whiteness (light skin, light eyes, light hair) do not really show up in the human gene pool earlier that 7-8 thousand years ago.

On the topic, just an observation, we have cats, and I have had cats my whole life more or less, and note the pounce and swatting habits.  The pre-pounce/pre-zooming pose is generally left hand on surface, right hand lifted and ready, butt wiggling for correct starting burst angle, and  after the pounce or launch, the right usually for the strike or first arm power in a zoom.  Also, they tend to swat or grab with the right hand as well.

As well as genetic left handedness there are other causes.  One common cause is foetal development being slowed during a particular phase of brain growth.  Oxygen starvation form the mother being an identified culprit.  This reduces the growth and number of the brain cells for a time.  Nature has a way of compensating once normal oxygen supply is restored and some lefties have shown to have enhanced abilities in other areas.  Spacial conceptualisation being one aspect.  This has shown in statistics that a higher proportion of architects and designers are left handed as opposed to the general population.

Why have you always to find an evolutionary advantage for a trait? Evolution doesn‚Äôt work like that. Sometimes a trait is there just because it is not so inconvenient that it gives a survival disadvantage. As long as left handed individuals can survive and reproduce the trait will persist in the population. It‚Äôs like asking what advantage brought to the selection of ginger hair. Random mutations appear all the time. If they don‚Äôt affect survival and reproduction ability they get transmitted to the offspring.

Parrots seem to have "footedness" preferences and the preferred foot differs from species to species. Amazon parrots are mostly left-footed. African greys are mostly right-footed. When parrots are babies, they try out both feet and eventually decide on a preferred foot, usually the one most common to their species.   Since sitting on a perch is an automatic function, manipulating food and other items is done with a preferred foot. (That's my opinion.) There are some right-footed Amazons and left-footed African greys, but they're in the minority. I'm not sure if the percentages of left vs. right are the same as they are in humans.   I haven't looked into this issue in a long time, so my info is pretty old. Hopefully, it's been studied scientifically by now...too tired to research it right now.

About combat sports, fighters are always expecting shots from the left hand. The difference is actually in the footwork. Footwork creates angles, and in a lefthanded fighter (southpaw), this means that certain strikes are going to land first because the distance is shorter. For example, southpaw cross beats orthodox jab and southpaw right hook beats orthodox cross.

Interestingly, most horses prefer their left side, that is to say, they find it easier to flex to the left, and take longer to learn skills on their right side. Horses have a split brains, so they literaly have to learn every skill twice, once for each side. There is a theory that the costume of mounting and leading a horse from his left side came because it means we bring our stronger right side in contact with their stronger left side. And another theory suggests that we unconsciously bred left-leaning horses because we found them easier to train and ride.

Isn't a cut in the left arm slightly more deadly than on the right arm, because the left arm has higher blood pressure since it is much closer to the aorta? Wouldn't right-handed creatures have a better survival rate, since having the left side exposed like the jugular is more lethal?
Left-handed man here. It is something I've had as far back as I can remember. Since so many modern tools like scissors are designed with right-handedness in mind, a lot of tasks feel very awkward being left-handed. In an effort to help mitigate this, I've been training myself to be ambidextrous. My right hand is functional, but still far inferior to my true dominant hand. Seeing how this trait developed so long ago really spoke to me. Handedness is something I've resented at times. At least now I understand why I have this handicap.

Yet more theories about handedness.  I suppose this makes more sense than anything else.    I'm left-handed with most things.  And although not at all athletic, I did most sports right-handed.  Use a hockey stick, tennis racket, golf club, or baseball bat, but bowling or say, throw say a basketball or football, I would do left-handed.  I think Frisbee would be either way.  I noticed this even more with Wii Sports years ago.  I'm also more comfortable using a computer mouse with my right hand, though I can use both.  But I write, draw, eat, use my phone, and almost everything else left-handed.
I guess it makes sense that freeing up limbs for other uses than mobility removes the restraint of having to be balanced. That could explain why we also see asymmetrical forelimbs in animals very distantly related to humans, like crabs, while in monkeys and apes that still primarily use their arms for moving around, it isn't so common.
